To provide a better explanation, the project manager wants to give an example of an intangible benefit. Which of the following is best for the project manager to use as an example?
explanation: The question divides potential benefits of a project into two groups, tangible and intangible. Tangible benefits are those that can be relatively easily expressed in monetary value, for example, anything that results in the production of a material, software, or service adds value to the organization’s assets, increases stockholder equity, and so on. Intangible benefits are those that cannot be directly and easily expressed in monetary value, however, in the long-term can bring value to the organization. Examples of intangible benefits could be brand recognition, public benefit, or trademarks. AMonetary assets

answers.answer_text: Monetary assets
Stockholder equity
Market share
Brand recognition

task: 2.13 Determine appropriate project methodology/methods and practices
question_text: An organization is to undertake a multi-phased project. The sponsor wants to pursue the project objectives as they have been planned but also wants to accommodate and adjust to new information and changes in the environment as the project progresses. Which project management approach should the project manager select for this project?
explanation: Determining the most appropriate methodology to manage a project can be difficult. Fortunately, project managers have plenty of tools in their toolbox. One option available to project managers is the ability to blend or utilize various aspects, approaches, and methods from various project management methodologies. This is referred to as a hybrid approach. In the scenario described, going forward with the upfront-developed plans and be agile to incoming data and changing environmental conditions is ripe for a hybrid approach.

answers.answer_text: Waterfall
Agile
Hybrid
Phased

question_text: Senior leadership has returned from a conference where they have learned about the agile practice of retrospectives. Even though the organization does not manage any projects in an agile manner, they mandate that from now on this ceremony is included in all projects. How should the outputs from the retrospectives be stored and managed?
explanation: Retrospectives are useful ceremonies – whether in an agile project or a hybrid project such as the one(s) described in the scenario. Retrospectives can be conducted at a regular cadence throughout a project (regardless of whether the deliverables are produced using iterations or not) to gather lessons learned and identify ways for the project team to adapt and improve. The aims of retrospectives are to find ways for the team to acknowledge what they are doing well and improve where they can. The outputs generated from the findings are meant mainly for the project team to reflect on and take necessary actions. Visibility and easy accessibility is key to ensuring that the outputs are not discarded or forgotten but actioned upon. ASenior leadership determines the location of the outputs and who may access the contents

answers.answer_text: Senior leadership determines the location of the outputs and who may access the contents
The project team stores the outputs in a location that the project manager can control and limit changes
The project team determines a location that is accessible for relevant stakeholders to view and track
The project manager establishes the location and allows the customer to view and make recommendations

question_text: Your project has many unknowns. When you submit a draft of the project management plan to the steering committee for approval, the committee rejects the plan because you have incorporated an iterative development lifecycle. The committee states that the project has a fixed deadline and budget, and, therefore, the project should use a waterfall framework. What is your best course of action?
explanation: The scenario describes a project with many unknowns and a fixed budget and timeline. Since the project has many unknowns, it will be difficult or impossible to fully decompose the project scope, as is typically done with a traditional waterfall framework. Thus, the project management plan will need to incorporate rolling wave planning or agile methodologies to progressively elaborate on the project's scope. Therefore, the steering committee member's suggestion to use a predictive framework may not be a viable strategy for this project. You, as the project manager, may need to use interpersonal and team skills to mentor the steering committee members on project management best practices and how agile methodologies might be employed in conjunction with a fixed timeline and budget. One approach that might be particularly effective in this situation would be to use the Dynamic Systems Development Method (DSDM) strategy of constraint-driven delivery. Constraint-driven delivery uses a prioritized list of features to ensure that the most important features are developed first and development continues until the project runs out of time or budget. This method ensures that the project finishes on time and budget with the highest priority features completed.

answers.answer_text: Describe to the steering committee how constraint-driven delivery can be used to complete the project while holding cost and time as fixed
Illustrate how the definition of a story point can be adjusted throughout product development to ensure that the project meets its objectives
Revise the plan as suggested by the steering committee since the committee has the power to approve or reject project management plans
Explain to the steering committee that agile uses the iron triangle and a robust change management system to ensure project objectives are met

task: 2.1 Execute project with the urgency required to deliver business value
question_text: An organization is considering a product development project. A needs assessment and the business case have already been completed. A management team wants the product to begin delivering business value as soon as possible. As part of pre-project work, what should be done next?
explanation: The scenario stipulates that pre-project work is still being performed and that the needs assessment and business case have already been completed. The only other project artifact that might be developed as part of pre-project work would be the benefits management plan. The benefits management plan should include target benefits and a timeframe for realizing the benefits. The minimum marketable features (MMF) represent the bare minimum of features and functionality that are required to release a product to derive business value. Thus the release of the MMF would be the earliest that business value could be derived from the project. Therefore, of the available options, the best alternative would be to record the release of the MMF as part of the timeframe for benefits realization in the benefits management plan. Note that even if one is not familiar with the term MMF, the question can still be answered by knowing what activities are typically carried out as part of pre-project work, by understanding what the benefits management plan includes, or by just eliminating choices that represent less plausible answers.

answers.answer_text: Developing a WBS that is decomposed to a level to support an MVP in the first release of the product under development
Creating a list of objectives and reasons for project initiation and including them in the project business documents
Recording the need to release an MMF as part of the timeframe for benefits realization in the benefits management plan
Documenting an incremental life cycle in the project charter as the approach needed to deliver business value quickly

question_text: As an agile coach, you have been requested to conduct a training session for a team assigned to their first agile project. You decide to start the session with the overview of the values outlined by the Agile Manifesto. Which of the following is one of those values?
explanation: According to the scenario, the team is going to work on an agile project. Agile methods are typically selected for projects where requirements are not clearly defined upfront. The requirements change, and new requirements emerge as the project progresses. In such an environment, planning scope in detail makes little sense and sometimes even impossible. Therefore, project teams should be ready for frequent changes. This idea of anticipating and embracing the need for change rather than following a detailed plan is what is expressed by the correct answer, "responding to change over following a plan." The incorrect answer choices are intentionally worded incorrectly by combining the different parts of the various Agile Manifesto values. ACustomer collaboration over comprehensive documentation

answers.answer_text: Customer collaboration over comprehensive documentation
Responding to change over following a plan
Individuals and interactions over processes and techniques
Working software over contract negotiation

task: 2.1 Execute project with the urgency required to deliver business value
question_text: An agile team is setting up a Kanban board with the goal of limiting the amount of work in progress (WIP). Which of the following should be considered by the team when setting up the queues of the Kanban board?
explanation: This question requires the student to know about Kanban and what practices or factors affect the amount of work in progress (WIP) that is assigned to the various processes depicted on a Kanban board. It is imperative to understand that high levels of work in progress lead to lower productivity, longer cycle times which create inefficiencies and backlogs that reduce productivity. The lower the cycle time, the more work can be processed. Multitasking causes a loss of productivity as there is a time penalty for the mind to task switch which results in tasks taking longer to complete. Longer task completion time increases the amount of work in progress and lowers productivity. Therefore, minimizing multitasking is an important consideration and is the correct answer choice. ACreating larger user stories helps minimize work in progress

answers.answer_text: Creating larger user stories helps minimize work in progress
Large amounts of work in progress often result in decreased cycle times
Multitasking extends the completion date of work and leaves work in progress longer
Large amounts of work in progress result in shorter wait times for customer feedback

task: 2.1 Execute project with the urgency required to deliver business value
question_text: Which of the following is considered a benefit of using iterative adaptive planning on an agile project?
explanation: An iterative adaptive planning approach supports what are often changing needs of the customer due to reprioritization of features or capabilities that can arise from a host of internal and external influences. Iterative adaptive planning allows for flexibility and minimizes the chances the plan and project outcomes will become outdated and not representative of customer needs. AEliminating project risk and uncertainty

answers.answer_text: Eliminating project risk and uncertainty
Supporting a project where the scope is fixed, and time and cost are variable
Predicting specific project milestone dates
Minimizing the chance that the plan will not meet the needs of the customer

question_text: A stakeholder approaches the scrum master and requests to see a report that shows the progress of the work remaining on the project at both the sprint level and the release level. Which of the following would be the best for the scrum master to provide the stakeholder with?
explanation: The sprint burndown chart is an information radiator in graph form that represents the team's remaining work in the sprint. Each day, team members update their tasks in the sprint backlog with the remaining hours for each task. These daily numbers are summarized and charted on the sprint burndown chart, which plots remaining work over the length of the sprint. As the team starts to work through their tasks, the idea is that the line will start to 'burn down', which means that the graph line will begin to follow a downward trend, representing a decreasing amount of work over the course of the sprint. Burndown charts can also be used to show the work remaining in a release. BProduct roadmap

answers.answer_text: Burndown chart
Product roadmap
Burnup chart
Sprint backlog

question_text: Midway into an agile project, new members join the team. The new team members are experienced with predictive project management approaches but have no agile background whatsoever. As the project progresses, the project manager notices that customer satisfaction started to drop. Which of the following would be the most likely reason for the decline in customer's satisfaction?
explanation: This question and corresponding best answer reinforce the importance of all team members understanding and embracing agile best practices and, in particular, the Agile Manifesto's value #4 that states, "Responding to change over following a plan", as well as the Agile Manifesto's principle #2, which states, "Welcome changing requirements, even late in development. Agile processes harness change for the customer's competitive advantage." Based on the way the scenario is framed, it is reasonable to assume that the new team members, who came from the predictive project management background, used to follow the project management plan that has been established early in project planning based on well-defined requirements that likely did not change much during project execution. Now that the team members moved to an agile project, where requirements are vague, frequently changing, and new requests are constantly introduced, the team members could not or did not want to collaborate. As a result, the decline in customer satisfaction would be a reasonable assumption and, therefore, of the choices provided, the best answer to the question asked. AThe new team members did not productively contribute to the team's velocity. BThe project manager did not invite the new team members to the kick-off meeting.

answers.answer_text: The new team members did not productively contribute to the team's velocity.
The project manager did not invite the new team members to the kick-off meeting.
The new team members resisted changes requested by the customer.
Customers are always unsatisfied regardless of how well the project is doing.

task: 2.13 Determine appropriate project methodology/methods and practices
question_text: After a few weeks of observation, an agile coach that was hired to guide a company through its transition from a waterfall to an agile project management approach told the company's management that the company still used waterfall methods to carry out its projects. Which of the following did the agile coach most likely notice that led them to reach that conclusion?
explanation: Small batch hand-offs, decentralized control, and product vision statements are typical practices used on agile projects. Waterfall, or traditional, project management uses a predictive lifecycle rather than the iterative and incremental approach that defines agile life cycles. Predictive life cycles expect to take advantage of high certainty around firm requirements, a stable team, and low risk. As a result, project activities are often executed in a serial manner. In an agile environment, the team expects requirements to change. The iterative and incremental approaches provide feedback to better plan the next part of the project. Of the available choices, only the use of a predictive life cycle would be indicative of an organization that has not fully made the transition from waterfall to agile methodologies. AA predictive life cycle was used to carry out project activities.

answers.answer_text: A predictive life cycle was used to carry out project activities.
Project teams delivered product increments in small batch hand-offs.
Management supported empowerment and decentralized control.
A product vision statement was mandated for each project.

task: 2.1 Execute project with the urgency required to deliver business value
question_text: During a retrospective meeting, an agile team used value stream mapping to improve processes that were causing bottlenecks in their last sprint. The team has implemented the retrospective decisions in the next sprint, but unfortunately, no improvement has been made. After the sprint was over, the scrum master who attended the retrospective, told the team that they were incorrectly applying the value stream mapping technique. The scrum master said the team was trying to improve something that was not part of the technique. Which of the following choices describes the issue the scrum master most likely noticed?
explanation: Value stream mapping is a lean manufacturing technique used to document, analyze, and improve the flow of information or materials required to produce a product or service for a customer. One of the significant benefits of value stream mapping is that it shows the entire picture. It shows how to optimize the whole by identifying waste, such as delays, multi-tasking, overloaded people, rework, late detection of problems, etc., which affects the quality and slows down delivery. Many agile practitioners focus on improving the team’s performance. Unfortunately, in many cases, the team is not the cause of the development problems, even though it looks that way. Therefore, of the choices provided, improving the performance of the team was the most likely reason the team has not succeeded in the process improvement and this was what the scrum master noticed during the retrospective. AImproving the total time from the beginning to the end of the entire value stream BIdentifying and reducing waste throughout the value stream

answers.answer_text: Improving the total time from the beginning to the end of the entire value stream
Identifying and reducing waste throughout the value stream
Improving the performance of the team throughout the value stream
Optimizing the whole process throughout the value stream

question_text: A member of an agile project team gathered data about the project and discovered an opportunity for improvement. The team member thinks that a change to the process used by the team to develop the product of the project would improve team performance. The team member approaches the scrum master for advice on the best way to implement the change. What advice can the scrum master give to the team member?
explanation: In addition to the initiative and creative thinking, incremental implementation of continuous improvements (Kaizen) requires a climate of trust, mutual respect, self-control, loyalty, and responsibility to colleagues and teammates. Because agile teams are empowered at the team level to define, implement, and maintain their own processes and procedures, any unilateral action taken by a team member, even as a measure of process improvement, carries a risk of breaking dependencies. Therefore, before implementing a change, it is important to involve others on an empowered team, in order to have their full commitment, trust, and support. AMake the change, see what happens, then report the results during the upcoming retrospective meeting

answers.answer_text: Make the change, see what happens, then report the results during the upcoming retrospective meeting
Submit a change request, wait for the approval of the change control board, and implement the change
Send an email to the functional manager to report the findings and ask for permission to make the change
Inform the team of the opportunity for improvement and, if the team supports it, implement the change

question_text: During the last few iterations of the agile project, the team members found themselves with many partially completed user stories. One team member suggested imposing an upper limit on the amount of work that the team takes on at any point during an iteration. What should an agile practitioner advise in this situation?
explanation: Work in progress (WIP) limits are part of the Kanban development system. By putting such a limit, agile teams ensure that the project's throughput increases, as partially completed work, which is considered waste, does not stay in the system. Having limits on WIP also reduces the cycle time to deliver completed work. AThe team should not set an upper limit on the work in progress because that would reduce the team's velocity.

answers.answer_text: The team should not set an upper limit on the work in progress because that would reduce the team's velocity.
The team should set an upper limit on the work in progress to reduce waste.
Consult the customer before setting an upper limit on the work in progress as the project goal is to add value to the customer.
Only the sponsor can approve limits that lower resource utilization and may lead to wasting project funds.

question_text: During a strategic planning meeting at the beginning of a new agile project, the attendees create a visual depiction of the product release and the functionality to be completed and available for each release. Who owns this artifact and works with others to maintain and update it?
explanation: The product roadmap is a visual depiction of the product releases and includes the functionality to be completed and available for each release. The product owner creates the roadmap in consultation with the project stakeholders and the project sponsor during the early planning stages of the project. The product owner is ultimately responsible for the project road map. As the project is executed, the product owner continues to work with project stakeholders and the sponsor to maintain and update the product roadmap to reflect the current state of the project. BProject sponsor DDevelopment team member

answers.answer_text: Product owner
Project sponsor
Scrum master
Development team member

question_text: An agile project is completed on schedule and budget, and the final product has the features that the customer values the most, even though they deviate from the original plan. The project retrospective shows that success can be attributed to the light change management process where the product owner reprioritized features based on customer feedback. What Agile Manifesto value was demonstrated most significantly in this scenario?
explanation: Agile Manifesto Value # 4 calls for responding to change as valued more than following a plan. All answer choices describe the Agile Manifesto values, but only one is actually supported by the situation presented in the scenario. A simple and light change management process allows the customer in collaboration with the product owner to initiate the reprioritization of user stories. In doing so, it is reasonable to assume that the project changed its original plan, or, as the scenario states, the final product deviated from the original plan. By responding to the customer's needs with the implementation of a light change management process, the product owner and team helped ensure that the final deliverables contain the features most valued by the customer and that the project was completed on schedule and within budget. In other words, the value of responding to change over following the plan was most significantly demonstrated in the scenario. AResponding to change over following a plan BCustomer collaboration over contract negotiation

answers.answer_text: Responding to change over following a plan
Customer collaboration over contract negotiation
Individuals and interactions over processes and tools
Working software over comprehensive documentation

task: 2.13 Determine appropriate project methodology/methods and practices
question_text: An agile practitioner would like to see their company start using Scrum for future projects, but getting buy-in at the executive level has been challenging since executives are not familiar with the benefits of agile methodologies. How should you describe to the executive team the benefits of using Scrum over other agile methodologies?
explanation: By being strict with artifacts, roles, and rules, Scrum allows teams to cope with the changes and unpredictability that are part of continuous discovery and learning. Scrum works because of its strict practices, roles, and rules. If one veers too far away from the prescribed methodology of Scrum, teams often fail to gain its full benefits. In Agile circles, when the teams say "we use Scrum, but...", they mean that they apply many aspects of Scrum but skip on one or more critical parts of the methodology. Not adhering to the methodology, in many cases, leads to the unsuccessful implementation of Scrum in the organization and wrong conclusions about Agile in general. AScrum does not have many roles or artifacts because it's more of a general agile mindset than a true methodology. BScrum has strict artifacts, roles, and rules, and although it's not flexible, it is most successful in providing benefits when applied correctly.

answers.answer_text: Scrum does not have many roles or artifacts because it's more of a general agile mindset than a true methodology.
Scrum has strict artifacts, roles, and rules, and although it's not flexible, it is most successful in providing benefits when applied correctly.
Scrum is lightweight and easily paired with other methodologies, making it flexible to anyone with any type of previous project management experience.
Scrum is the least likely agile methodology to be used by organizations due to its overly strict roles, rules, and artifacts.

task: 2.13 Determine appropriate project methodology/methods and practices
question_text: Crystal family of methods has been chosen for the upcoming very complex project involving multiple teams to develop a critical medical application. What methodology using the Crystal grid would an agile practitioner recommend for this project?
explanation: Crystal is a family of methods, designed to address implementation concerns while using Agile methodologies for different types of projects involving different team sizes. Crystal family of methods is frequently represented by a grid with team size shown on the horizontal axis and the project criticality on the vertical axis. Project criticality refers to how big is the impact from a defect found in the system. In the reference provided the author describes that "Moving to the right in the grid means coordinating more people, which requires a heavier methodology. Using the crystal metaphor, moving right corresponds to choosing a darker color. Movement up in the grid corresponds to more potential damage from the system and the use of more rigor and ceremony. Using the crystal metaphor, moving up means increasing 'hardiness'." In the scenario described in the question, the project involves multiple teams working on a project to develop a critical medical application. For a larger team size, a darker color methodology should be selected. For more critical application a harder crystal methodology should be selected. Therefore, overall, a darker color and a harder crystal methodology from the upper right corner should be selected for the project.

answers.answer_text: A clearer color and a softer crystal methodology from the lower left corner
A clearer color and a harder crystal methodology from the upper left corner
A darker color and a harder crystal methodology from the upper right corner
A darker color and a softer crystal methodology from the lower right corner

task: 2.1 Execute project with the urgency required to deliver business value
question_text: During the feasibility stage, stakeholders who are unfamiliar with Agile are concerned about preliminary estimates being too uncertain causing the project to exceed budget and last longer than expected. Which statement about agile estimating and planning should the product owner communicate to the stakeholders to alleviate their fears?
explanation: Planning and estimating at the feasibility stage of an agile project is not about determining a firm schedule and budget. These must be determined iteratively and incrementally. At this stage, the focus is on determining value to the customer and understanding what should be built and how long the project will take and cost. As the project progresses, planning and estimating are done incrementally and iteratively, which, in turn, improves the accuracy of both the time and the project cost estimates. APlanning and estimating at the feasibility stage is simply about determining an appropriate deadline or schedule for the project.

answers.answer_text: Planning and estimating at the feasibility stage is simply about determining an appropriate deadline or schedule for the project.
The value of the work as well as planning and estimating for the work to be done are determined iteratively and incrementally.
Estimates are not needed to create plans for purposes of marketing, training, and release activities until deliverables are produced.
Accurate estimates will be available during iteration Zero, therefore by the time the actual work starts, precise plan can be provided

task: 2.13 Determine appropriate project methodology/methods and practices
question_text: A project manager experienced in both traditional and agile methods explains the differences and similarities between the two approaches to the sponsor. To make the point, the project manager provides an example of a misconception typically associated with agile methods. Which of the following is the misconception that the project manager most likely provided?
explanation: One of the answer choices represents a misconception about agile, assuming that only agile projects are value-driven. In reality, both agile and traditional project management approaches can be value-driven. However, in agile project management, delivering value iteratively and incrementally is emphasized, and the project team focuses on producing high-value features early in the project. In contrast, traditional project management typically delivers value at the end of the project after all the project components have been completed. Agile values are explicit and integrated into every aspect of the project, and the team continuously assesses the project's value proposition and adapts it as needed. Overall, both agile and traditional project management approaches can be value-driven, but the way they deliver value may differ. Therefore, of the choices provided, saying that only projects that are performed using agile methods are value-driven is the misconception that the project manager described to the sponsor. AA charter should be developed for any project, either traditional or agile. BOnly projects that are performed using agile methods are value-driven.

answers.answer_text: A charter should be developed for any project, either traditional or agile.
Only projects that are performed using agile methods are value-driven.
Both traditional and agile methods allow for changes throughout the project.
Too much planning introduces risk in projects carried out using agile methods.

task: 3.2 Evaluate and deliver project benefits and value
question_text: An agile team is working on a software release with an initial backlog of 720 story points. During sprints two to four, new user stories have been added. The following burndown chart represents the progress the team has made so far. The project manager has been requested to update stakeholders on the project's status. What should the project manager tell the stakeholders?
explanation: A release burndown chart is a visual representation, which displays the amount of work left to complete the target commitment for a product release. The chart accomplishes this by displaying the actual amount of work remaining to complete the release. The concept behind the burndown chart is that the amount of remaining work will burn down as time goes by until the team gets to 100% done for the release. New user stories have been added during the sprints two to four. If the team did not complete any work during those sprints, the curve of the burndown chart that represents the actual work completed would have pointed upwards. However, since the curve is flat, one can imply the team has completed the work that has been added, but not more than that. In other words, the team was only able to keep up with the scope added during these sprints. AThere is not enough information for the project manager to provide any status. BThe project team will not be able to complete the release on time.

answers.answer_text: There is not enough information for the project manager to provide any status.
The project team will not be able to complete the release on time.
The team was only able to keep up with the scope added during these sprints.
The project is progressing more quickly than initially planned.

task: 2.1 Execute project with the urgency required to deliver business value
question_text: An agile team has to implement a new payroll system. The product owner is a payroll expert but is not familiar with agile planning. What advice should an agile coach offer to the product owner?
explanation: Agile encourages the creation of an environment that facilitates face-to-face planning events with stakeholders, customers, and team members. Having a dedicated space for the team collaboration makes planning activities visible and transparent. An agile coach would need to mentor the product owner on agile adaptive planning techniques. The product owner should make time to be available to the team, provide feedback, and any information in order for the team to move forward. The plan will be evolving, and the product owner will be grooming the backlog frequently as changes are coming. Information radiators are invaluable tools for stakeholders to view project progress. ACreate an environment that facilitates face-to-face planning events involving relevant project stakeholders

answers.answer_text: Create an environment that facilitates face-to-face planning events involving relevant project stakeholders
Generate a requirements document for the team to develop the product exactly per customer specifications
Draft a project plan and send it to stakeholders for approval to ensure everybody are on the same page
Develop a Gantt chart listing project deliverables to get necessary resources from the project sponsor

question_text: An agile project leader wants to ensure that the product vision does not fade away in the team members' minds throughout the course of the project. Which of the following would be the best way for the agile leader to achieve that goal?
explanation: Visioning and goal setting have been identified time after time as key ingredients of project success. A project leader’s primary role is to facilitate the creation of a product vision and guide the team toward making that vision a reality. Product vision drives product roadmap; the product roadmap drives release plan; the release plan establishes the iterations. The product vision is not always static and, in some cases, can be adjusted over the course of the project, especially an agile project, where requirements often and constantly change. Therefore, by re-communicating the product vision at the beginning of each iteration (or milestone), project leaders create a sense of purpose in the endeavor that will motivate people to work toward the common goal. APresent the product vision statement at the kickoff meeting BUpload the product vision statement to the company's internal website

answers.answer_text: Present the product vision statement at the kickoff meeting
Upload the product vision statement to the company's internal website
Email the product vision statement to all project stakeholders
Re-communicate the product vision at the beginning of each iteration

question_text: In traditional project management, the term for frequent changes in scope, is called 'scope creep'. In agile project management, what is true of frequent changes in scope?
explanation: In their book, The Software Project Manager's Bridge to Agility, Michele Sliger and Stacia Broderick state: "Changes to the scope in agile projects are handled through the utilization of a prioritized product backlog. Adding or reprioritizing a feature in the product backlog constitutes what in traditional project management is known as scope change, or 'scope creep'". In agile terminology, however, it is called 'expected change'. One of the twelve guiding agile principles mentions that changes are welcomed, even late in development. Agile processes harness change for the customer's competitive advantage and to meet the changing needs of the customers.

answers.answer_text: It does not exist because the scope is defined upfront
It is expected and accepted because the requirements are unknown upfront and change regularly
It is expected because the scope and requirements often change during the execution of agile projects
It is expected and managed using agile change control management system

question_text: ThePMBOK®Guidedefines project charter as a document that "formally authorizes the existence of a project and provides the project manager with the authority to apply organizational resources to project activities." Developing project charters on agile projects:
explanation: Be suspicious when you see answer choices with absolute statements such as 'never, 'always', 'must', etc. With some exceptions, choices containing these words represent incorrect answers. It's not a MUST to follow thePMBOK®Guideprocess while developing a project charter on an agile project. On the other hand, there is nothing that stops you from following thePMBOK®Guideprocess to develop a charter on an agile project. Agile is paperless is a made-up statement. Theoretically, you can go paperless on agile, but it is hard to see how this would be implemented in real-life situations. While not ideal, the only correct choice is the one that states that agile projects do not necessarily require a formal document that represents a project charter. As stated by the authors in one of the references provided, "There are two ways to develop a project charter in an agile environment. One is to continue along the traditional route of preparing the paperwork needed in order to obtain approval. The other way presumes that either provisional funding has been awarded or that tacit approval has already occurred without the need for internal paperwork." AMust follow the PMBOK® Guide processes

answers.answer_text: Must follow the PMBOK® Guide processes
Must not follow the PMBOK® Guide processes
Is not required because Agile is paperless
Does not necessarily require a formal document

question_text: An agile team has decided to use brand-new technology to develop a high priority user story. However, after several unsuccessful attempts, they concluded they could not proceed. The team tried out other approaches, brought external experts but nothing worked. What is the next step for the team to take?
explanation: Not all problems have solutions, at least within a reasonable period or at a reasonable cost. In such situations, it could be better to let it go regardless of how painful or shameful this could be. Even though giving up does not sound good, this is the only reasonable action the team can take in this case. They have tried everything, but nothing worked. Therefore, the team should inform all relevant project stakeholders and reset expectations accordingly. Agile teams and leaders have to ensure that issues are resolved by appropriate team members or stakeholders. If a resolution cannot be found, expectations in light of issues that cannot be resolved in order to maximize the value delivered should be reset accordingly. AGive up, inform the project stakeholders, and reset expectations accordingly BEscalate the issue to the project sponsor and request they provide a solution

answers.answer_text: Give up, inform the project stakeholders, and reset expectations accordingly
Escalate the issue to the project sponsor and request they provide a solution
Create an alternative user story of similar size that can be developed properly
Implement appropriate risk response from the project risk management plan

task: 2.1 Execute project with the urgency required to deliver business value
question_text: An agile project is on track, the team performance is stable, and the project stakeholders are happy. Despite this, the team members decide to implement a new development approach for the next iteration, hoping to enhance project performance even further. Unfortunately, the approach fails, and, as a result, the iteration goal is not met. Was the team right trying to implement the new approach?
explanation: Agile leaders should create a safe environment for experimentation where team members can try new approaches without being fearful of failure. Even if the project is already delivering value to the customer, trying a new approach can lead to even greater value being delivered, if successful. Having said that, experimentation is not the sole goal of agile. Therefore, if a project is on the edge of failure, and/or the timeline is extremely tight, it's probably not the best time or place to try new approaches. In this question, the project is on track, the team performance is good, and the stakeholders are happy. The scenario does not imply that the new approach has the potential to put the entire project in jeopardy. Rather, the scenario describes a situation where the team may want to start experimenting with new approaches trying to find an alternative and possibly more effective way to deliver additional value to the customer going forward. ANo. When a project is on track and the stakeholders are happy, the team should stick to the approach that works and refrain from trying other approaches.

answers.answer_text: No. When a project is on track and the stakeholders are happy, the team should stick to the approach that works and refrain from trying other approaches.
Yes. Even when a project is on track and the stakeholders are happy, the team members may try a new approach if they feel the approach can maximize the value.
No. The team should have set up a meeting with the stakeholders and proceed with the new approach only if the stakeholders were all in agreement.
Yes. Regardless of how well the project is doing, agile project management is all about exploration and experimentation, trial and error, success and failure.

question_text: An agile project team meets with the product owner, project manager, and other key project stakeholders to discuss the multiple levels of planning that the project will have to go through. The participants acknowledge that planning will be required at the release and iteration level. The project manager indicates that planning will also be required on a day-to-day basis. Which of the following does the project manager refer to?
explanation: Planning in agile is done at multiple levels: strategy, portfolio, product, release, iteration, and day. Agile teams are mainly involved in the release, iteration, and daily planning activities. User stories to be developed in the release are planned, as the name implies, at the release level. At the next level, the iteration, the product owner, and the team create the iteration backlog and prioritize the user stories based on value to the customer, risk, and other pre-defined criteria. Once the iteration is in progress, the team meets daily to report on the tasks completed the day before, coordinate the individual activities that lead up to the completion of a task for the current day, as well as to inform of any impediments to progress. ACarrying out an architectural spike to reduce technical risks as early as possible in the project BSynchronizing and coordinating the individual activities that lead up to the completion of a task

answers.answer_text: Carrying out an architectural spike to reduce technical risks as early as possible in the project
Synchronizing and coordinating the individual activities that lead up to the completion of a task
Acquiring project team members and assigning the tasks per the resource management plan
Coordinating team activities with other teams working on the same project in the organization

question_text: In their first iteration, an agile team completed only half of the planned work. It turns out that before the current project began, the team members were requested to provide ongoing support for the prior release. Angry project stakeholders meet with the scrum master and complain that supporting prior releases should have never been included in the project plans. How should the scrum master respond?
explanation: In the reference provided, the author writes, "In addition to making progress on a project, many teams are responsible for support and maintenance of another system. It may be a prior version of the product they are working on, or it may be an unrelated system. When a team makes a commitment to complete a set of stories during an iteration, they need to do so with their maintenance and support load in mind." In the scenario provided, it seems as the team knew that they were responsible for supporting products that were not associated with completing the work on the current project. However, the team most likely missed to account for this work during the iteration/release planning. Therefore, the failure to complete and deliver the planned work lies with the team. However, this does not mean the scrum master should remove support work from the next iteration onward. While the situation is not ideal, the scrum master should explain that routine work of supporting prior releases may be included in project plans and try to come to a reasonable solution with the stakeholders, solution that would allow the team to complete the current project and, at the same time, support the prior releases, without too much overtime work. One approach to account for work not directly related to the current project is first to allocate a percentage or an average amount of time typically required to accomplish these routine tasks. Once this is done, the time left in the iteration can be used to estimate the number of user stories (or story points, features, etc.) of the current project that can be reasonably completed in the time remaining. Another alternative would be to place a user story of a size equivalent to the estimated size of the support work in the iteration backlog. AAgree with the stakeholders and remove all further support work from the next iterations

answers.answer_text: Agree with the stakeholders and remove all further support work from the next iterations
Ignore the stakeholders' complain and instruct the team to continue supporting the prior releases
Explain that routine work of supporting prior releases may be included in project plans
Request that from now on the team work overtime to complete both the planned work and support

task: 2.13 Determine appropriate project methodology/methods and practices
question_text: An agile team is struggling with practicing agile in an organization that operates in a highly regulated industry that requires projects to use waterfall methodologies. What approach may an agile coach recommend in this situation?
explanation: While the agile project management approach has proven itself to be a very effective way to deliver projects, it is not a silver bullet. Some industries, such as finance, healthcare, government, have valid reasons for using the traditional waterfall approach. On the other hand, a project and its organization may benefit from agile best practices if agile methods can co-exist with the traditional methods. In the reference provided, the authors state, "None of these requirements will cease to exist simply because the teams are employing agile practices. Instead, the teams must learn to factor these organizational requirements into their existing agile processes, and management must begin the investigative work of determining how to streamline these requirements and activities, eliminating wasteful process, so that they don't hamper the project." AComply with the organizational requirements and abandon the team's existing agile practices BFactor the organizational requirements into the team's existing agile practices

answers.answer_text: Comply with the organizational requirements and abandon the team's existing agile practices
Factor the organizational requirements into the team's existing agile practices
Continue practicing agile methods but have the changes reviewed by the change control board
Persuade the organization's senior management to transition to agile practices

task: 2.13 Determine appropriate project methodology/methods and practices
question_text: The agile team coach receives an email request for a copy of the project management plan. How should the team coach respond to this request from a stakeholder who is unfamiliar with agile?
explanation: In this situation, the project stakeholder is not familiar with agile methods of planning and has requested for a copy of the project management plan, an artifact, which is typical in traditional, predictive project planning. One of the responsibilities of an agile coach is to educate the organization about agile practices and methodologies. The agile coach should contact the stakeholder and take this opportunity to educate and inform the stakeholder that agile uses adaptive planning rather than predictive planning. The coach can introduce the stakeholder to the product backlog, iterations, releases, iteration and release planning, as well as other planning artifacts such as story maps and product road maps. The coach can then draw parallels between agile artifacts and those used in traditional predictive project management. Introducing key concepts of adaptive planning such as agile discovery and progressive elaboration will help the stakeholder understand agile practices and explain why in agile, a traditional project management plan is not used to plan, monitor and execute the project from start to finish. ASend the stakeholder a story map or project roadmap BExplain the adaptive planning approach used by agile projects

answers.answer_text: Send the stakeholder a story map or project roadmap
Explain the adaptive planning approach used by agile projects
Suggest the stakeholder attend an iteration retrospective and ask their planning questions
Ask the product owner to address the stakeholder's questions

task: 2.1 Execute project with the urgency required to deliver business value
question_text: An agile practitioner is looking for ways to optimize the process of producing deliverables for the next iterations and release. Which tool should be considered for this task?
explanation: Value stream mapping is a lean manufacturing technique that was originally developed by Toyota. The purpose of value stream mapping is to analyze and improve the flow of materials and information during the development of a product and make changes as necessary to increase the value of the product delivered to the customer. It is intended to provide the individual performing the value stream mapping process a better understanding of the system used to create a product by mapping out the process steps and details. It is usually focused on the entire development environment, as opposed to just one aspect of it. Value stream mapping helps teams 'see' processes and process interactions. This technique provides a deeper understanding of where potential roadblocks or constraints exist in a process which allows teams to optimize workflow and eliminate wasteful practices. The single most important goal of using value stream mapping is to identify and eliminate waste. BRelease planning CValue stream mapping

answers.answer_text: Story boarding
Release planning
Value stream mapping
Agile modeling

question_text: A stakeholder approaches a team member and asks for a quick update on the current sprint's progress. How should the team member respond?
explanation: Information radiators, also known as big visible charts (BVCs), are visible, physical or digital displays that provide information to the rest of the organization, enabling timely knowledge sharing. Examples include burndown and burnup charts. Information radiators are usually displayed in a visible area, where stakeholders can quickly get information at a glance. A quick update on the current sprint's progress, as requested by the stakeholder in the scenario provided, can be easily obtained by simply looking at the burn charts where the amount of completed work (on the burnup chart) or the number of remaining work (on the burndown chart) is displayed. Therefore, referring the stakeholder to the big visible charts is the best course of action for the team member. ADirect the stakeholder to the scrum master BRefer the stakeholder to the big visible charts

answers.answer_text: Direct the stakeholder to the scrum master
Refer the stakeholder to the big visible charts
Invite the stakeholder to the daily standup
Invite the stakeholder to the sprint retrospective

question_text: After a successful demonstration of the product increment to the customer, the agile team begins developing the next set of user stories. Midway through the iteration, the customer requests an important change to be made to the product. The team realizes that the change will require significant modifications to the code. What should the team do first?
explanation: In iteration-based agile, teams plan their work based on their capacity. When iteration planning is complete, the iteration goal is established, and work on the iteration begins, no additional features or changes can be accepted unless the change is so critical that not implementing it may render the currently developed product increment useless/obsolete. Typically, when new features or changes are requested while the team is midway into an iteration, the features/changes should be added to the product backlog for further prioritization. If the feature/change is important, like in the scenario described, the feature/change is likely to be planned for the next iteration. However, this decision lies with the product owner and/or customer. Additionally, the team realizes that the change will require significant modifications to the code. Therefore, expecting the team to change the code in the current iteration may be unrealistic. An architectural spike will likely be required to assess the feasibility of the change. However, none of those details are provided in the scenario and/or answer choices. Ideally, the correct answer choice would indicate that the team should conduct an architectural spike and consult with the product owner. However, this choice is not provided. Therefore, of those available, considering the implementation of the change in the next iteration is the best answer to the question asked. AStop the work on the current iteration and consult with the scrum master BReject the change since it requires significant modifications to the code

answers.answer_text: Stop the work on the current iteration and consult with the scrum master
Reject the change since it requires significant modifications to the code
Implement the change since the customer indicated the change was important
Consider the implementation of the change in the next iteration

task: 2.13 Determine appropriate project methodology/methods and practices
question_text: For their upcoming agile project, the team members want to visualize and manage their workflow and limit work in progress without being constrained by strict timeboxed iterations. What method would best fit the needs of the team?
explanation: The Kanban method has its roots in the lean manufacturing system. Some agile practitioners do not even consider Kanban an agile method because it uses a pull system to move work items through the product development process, unlike other agile methods, such as Scrum, eXtreme Programming (XP), or any other generic agile method, where the work is planned in advance and scheduled using predefined timeboxed iterations. Although other agile methods can also visualize and manage the workflow and limit work in progress, those techniques are considered primarily among Kanban core principles. Therefore, if the team wants to visualize and manage their workflow and limit work in progress without being constrained by strict timeboxed iterations, Kanban would fit their needs best, thus making Kanban the best answer among the choices given. BeXtreme Programming (XP) DCumulative flow diagram

answers.answer_text: Scrum
eXtreme Programming (XP)
Kanban
Cumulative flow diagram

question_text: An organization has established a controlling project management office (PMO). The first task of the PMO is to update the guidelines for project compliance in the organization. Which of the following could the PMO enforce? (Choose three.)
explanation: There are several types of PMOs in an organization, with varying degrees of influence: supportive, controlling, and directive. A controlling PMO provides support, but also require compliance. Compliance may involve the adoption of project management frameworks or methodologies; the use of specific templates, forms, and tools; and conformance to governance frameworks. However, neither a controlling PMO nor any other type of PMO for that matter enforces local health regulations. A controlling PMO does not decide on the use of management reserves either. It is the directive, not controlling PMO, that assigns project managers and take control of the projects by directly managing them. AUse of particular project management methodologies BAdoption of specific templates, forms, and tools

answers.answer_text: Use of particular project management methodologies
Adoption of specific templates, forms, and tools
Adherence to local health regulations
Conformance to governance frameworks
Assignment of project managers by the PMO
Release of management reserves

task: 2.1 Execute project with the urgency required to deliver business value
question_text: The latest software released to the customer in the first project phase is full of defects. The customer is angry and demands that the development of the new release, which is planned to be delivered in the second phase, is much more transparent. The customer wants to see the team’s results more regularly and without very long development intervals in-between. Which of the following could the project team introduce in the second phase to better comply with the customer's demand? (Choose four.)
explanation: The scenario implies that the first phase of the project was likely delivered using a waterfall project management approach, where the software had been developed in one long iteration and deployed at the customer site. This approach, especially with software development products, often results in more defects in comparison to the iterative and incremental approach. What customer demands for the second phase can be achieved by incorporating agile practices, making the second phase hybrid. For many project teams who need to introduce more agility, setting up regular timeboxes and frequent retrospectives help organize the team's work in close collaboration with the customer. In addition to a more iterative approach, an incremental delivery using a backlog is another good first step towards agility in a project. According to the scenario, the team has problems with poor quality – test-driven development practices can address that. AA cadence with regular timeboxes

answers.answer_text: A cadence with regular timeboxes
Regular and frequent retrospectives
Optimization at the level of each individual team member
Test-driven development practices
Incremental delivery using a backlog
Limiting the number of changes before the software is released

question_text: With the seventh sprint completed and three more to go, the performing organization establishes a new policy that all project changes must be approved by at least one member of the change control board (CCB). A scrum master finds that compliance with the policy will create an impediment to the project's progress. What is the scrum master's best course of action?
explanation: Agile best practices do not supersede organizational policies. The scrum master, as a diligent, respectful, and caring steward, has an obligation to comply with all organizational policies, even those that the scrum master considers redundant. In an agile environment, the product owner serves as the voice of the customer and can ensure that changes are consistent with the overall project goals. In this scenario, any member of the change control board (CCB) can approve a change. Under the circumstances described in the scenario, complying with the new policy and, at the same time, adding the product owner as a member of the CCB would effectively grant approval authority to the product owner, thus providing a reasonable solution to the problem statement. However, if the request to grant the product owner the approval authority is denied, the scrum master will need to continue submitting change requests even if it negatively impacts the project. ASubmit the change requests after the changes have been implemented to avoid delays BComply with the new policy but request that the product owner be added as a member of the CCB

answers.answer_text: Submit the change requests after the changes have been implemented to avoid delays
Comply with the new policy but request that the product owner be added as a member of the CCB
Use discretion and only submit change requests that impact the project budget
Adhere to agile best practices and bypass the new change control process

task: 3.2 Evaluate and deliver project benefits and value
question_text: The current sprint's goal is to develop subcomponents that will be integrated into functional deliverables. Due to the highly specialized nature of the subcomponents, each team member will have to complete their development tasks individually. Despite this, the project leader wants to ensure that the activities among the team members are properly coordinated. What is the best course of action for the project leader?
explanation: Systems thinking requires that project leaders and teams recognize, evaluate, and respond to system interactions. Projects may have subsystems, and project deliverables can have subcomponents. Ideally, agile project team members will collaborate in real-time to produce the deliverables for each iteration. However, the scenario describes a situation in which the highly specialized nature of the subcomponents makes real-time collaboration unrealistic, forcing the team members to perform their work individually. These circumstances elevate the importance of participation in the daily standup meetings to even a higher degree. The daily standup meeting is a brief collaboration meeting in which the team reviews progress from the previous day, states intentions for the current day, and highlights any impediments. Under the circumstances provided in this scenario, this daily meeting might be the project team members' only opportunity to coordinate their activities to ensure that each subcomponent can be integrated into a functional deliverable later in the project. ADuring sprint planning, review the interdependencies between the development tasks on the project schedule network diagram

answers.answer_text: During sprint planning, review the interdependencies between the development tasks on the project schedule network diagram
Ask for the team members' improvement suggestions while transferring the knowledge gained to the lessons learned repository
Ensure that changes to the subcomponents are approved by the CCB to strengthen their alignment with the functional deliverables
Encourage the project team members to actively participate in the discussions that take place during the daily standup meetings

task: 3.3 Evaluate and address external business environment changes for impact on scope
question_text: During a sprint retrospective, a project team has identified external interdependencies as a key factor impacting project performance. explanation: Successful project leaders need to recognize, evaluate, and respond to system interactions. Keeping in mind that the question is asking for the 'least' likely approach to be employed by the team ("except for"), each of the incorrect answer choices represents a key factor that supports systems thinking. While an effective agile practice for the project described in the scenario, the caves and common approach only affects the development team and does not influence external interdependencies. Therefore, adopting the caves and common approach is the 'least' likely course of action for the team and scrum master. Having greater empathy with other business areas
Employing critical thinking with a focus on the big picture
Seeking external review and advice

task: 2.13 Determine appropriate project methodology/methods and practices
question_text: An organization is about to undertake three complex agile projects that will have interdependencies between them. Each project has a team consisting of six members and is led by a scrum master. The projects are part of a bigger program. What is the best strategy for the program manager to coordinate the work between the projects?
explanation: Project leaders need to recognize, evaluate, and respond to system interactions. When interdependencies exist, project leaders need to adopt systems thinking. Systems thinking entails taking a holistic view of how projects and project parts interact with each other. Systems thinking is critical in dealing with complex projects with interdependencies so the organization can maximize the delivery of business value through the various value streams. When agile teams need to coordinate their activities to address interdependencies between various projects, as in the scenario provided, a scaling approach is often used. One scaling approach is to incorporate a scrum of scrums. A scrum of scrums is a meeting where representatives from each scrum team meet to coordinate their activities between the projects. Under the circumstances described in the scenario, where three complex agile projects with interdependencies between them are planned to be carried out, suggesting that the scrum masters establish a scrum of scrums between the projects is the best course of action for the program manager. ASuggest that the scrum masters establish a scrum of scrums between the projects BAllow the project teams to work independently to expedite the delivery of value

answers.answer_text: Suggest that the scrum masters establish a scrum of scrums between the projects
Allow the project teams to work independently to expedite the delivery of value
Combine the project teams into one large scrum team led by a scrum master
Ensure that all project activities are scheduled during initial project planning

task: 2.13 Determine appropriate project methodology/methods and practices
question_text: A vendor has been awarded a contract to develop a software module for a customer who develops a new banking application. The development team of the vendor is accustomed to agile methods, but the contract with the customer requires that the module be developed using a waterfall framework. Another example would be to schedule daily standup meetings to help the developers coordinate their activities for the day and surface any impediments. These are just two examples of agile best practices that could be incorporated into the project without violating the requirement for the use of a predictive framework. AUse an incremental and iterative approach for the software development but deliver the module in a single release

answers.answer_text: Use an incremental and iterative approach for the software development but deliver the module in a single release
Gather all requirements upfront and ensure that no changes are made throughout the course of the project
Use a predictive approach as specified in the contract and avoid all practices associated with agile development
To the extent contractually permitted, incorporate as many agile best practices as appropriate for the project

task: 2.13 Determine appropriate project methodology/methods and practices
question_text: After successfully completing several one-week iterations, an agile team is in agreement that the weekly iteration retrospectives have not been productive as the team is already working very efficiently. The team members say that holding weekly retrospectives is not the best use of their time. What is the best course of action for the project leader?
explanation: Project leaders should tailor the development approach based on context. In the scenario, weekly iterations have been adopted for the project life cycle. If the team members are in agreement that they are not deriving sufficient benefit from these weekly meetings and their time is better spent elsewhere, the project leader might recommend adjusting the cadence to better suit the needs of the project team. One may argue that iteration retrospectives are an agile best practice, and all agile best practices must be followed to the letter. While the concepts of tailoring and following agile best practices might sometimes conflict, it is the responsibility of the project leader and team to balance these conflicts to achieve the project goals while maximizing the delivery of business value for the performing organization and its customers. question_text: A new program consists of five projects, each performed by a scrum team. Throughout the program life cycle, various deliverables from each of the scrum teams will serve as inputs to other teams. What is the best strategy for each of the scrum masters to navigate this complexity?
explanation: Project leaders need to continually evaluate and navigate project complexity. One common source of complexity is system behavior, which is the result of dynamic interdependencies. Applying systems thinking throughout the project life cycle is one way of navigating this increased complexity. answers.answer_text: Seek the program manager's approval of the deliverables before they move from one team to another
Apply systems thinking throughout the project life cycle

task: 2.13 Determine appropriate project methodology/methods and practices
question_text: A company operating in a high-tech industry with new technologies emerging every few months charters a project that is expected to have unstable requirements for its whole duration. A project manager is assigned, and the sponsor requests the project manager to suggest a strategy that best supports the adaptability and resiliency of the project in this environment. Which of the following capabilities should the project leader leverage for this strategy?
explanation: Project leaders should embrace adaptability and resiliency. Adaptability refers to the ability to respond to changing conditions, while resiliency is the ability to absorb impacts and recover quickly from a setback or failure. In the scenario, the organization operates in the high-tech industry with new technologies emerging every few months, and the project is expected to have unstable requirements for its entire duration. Adaptive (agile) methodologies are best suited to projects with unstable requirements. A predictive framework typically requires the project to be planned in detail upfront, and changes are tightly controlled. Thus, a predictive framework works well when the requirements are well understood up front and are not likely to change. Conversely, an iterative and incremental life cycle incorporates planning, execution, and feedback within each iteration permitting the requirements and deliverables to be progressively elaborated. Short feedback loops are a fundamental component of agile projects. Integrating short feedback loops into the project workflow enhances adaptability and resiliency by ensuring that the project team can collect fast and frequent feedback from relevant stakeholders and increases the opportunities to adapt to emerging technologies and changes. AExpediting decision making to occur at the first possible moment

answers.answer_text: Expediting decision making to occur at the first possible moment
Acquiring project team members with a highly specialized set of skills
Limiting the exposure to tacit knowledge and leveraging explicit knowledge
Incorporating short feedback loops to adapt the product and process quickly

task: 2.13 Determine appropriate project methodology/methods and practices
question_text: A project has been subjected to setbacks caused by various internal and external factors. As a result, some of the incomplete user stories from the previous sprints had to be reassigned to the next ones. The team members are frustrated and unsure of their ability to meet the project goals. What should the project leader recommend to the team members to enhance their adaptability and resiliency and improve project performance?
explanation: Projects rarely perform exactly as initially planned; therefore, project leaders must embrace adaptability and resiliency to improve project outcomes. Adaptability refers to the ability to respond to changing conditions, while resiliency is the ability to absorb impacts and the ability to recover quickly from a setback or failure. In the scenario, the project leader is asked to suggest the best course of action for the team to enhance their adaptability and resiliency and improve project performance. One strategy that can achieve that goal is the regular inspection and adaption of project work and the processes used by the team to produce project deliverables. The sprint retrospective is a standard agile ceremony that provides the project team with the opportunity to inspect and adapt their practices, identify improvement opportunities and, once found, exploit them to enhance project performance. This practice provides the project team with the opportunity to learn and adapt their practices while operating within a dynamic project environment, thus strengthening adaptability and resiliency. AOrganize periodic team-building events to reduce team member's frustration BIdentify critical path activities and focus on their timely completion

answers.answer_text: Organize periodic team-building events to reduce team member's frustration
Identify critical path activities and focus on their timely completion
Regularly inspect and adapt work process and exploit improvement opportunities
Ensure the project does not deviate from the initially prioritized backlog

question_text: After several sprints, the project team encounters significant resistance to the required changes from some of the impacted stakeholders. The resistance to the change poses a threat to the successful outcome of the project. The team members feel handling the issue is beyond their sphere of influence or authority. In this question, the answer choices provide a very brief description of each deliverable that contains a defining characteristic of a particular approach. Scrum is an agile methodology that is characterized by timeboxed periods of planning and development during which a product increment is produced. These development periods are referred to as sprints, at the end of which, a potentially releasable product increment with business value is delivered. When using a predictive life cycle (sometimes referred to as traditional waterfall), the project's deliverables and requirements are defined upfront during initial project planning. The project scope is generally fully decomposed into a work breakdown structure (WBS). Note that rolling wave planning may defer some of the decomposition of the project scope, but most of the requirements are still defined upfront, albeit at a higher level. Large projects (or even deliverables) may have dependencies with other related projects and project teams. This situation requires some level of coordination between the teams. Scaling frameworks provide a structure for the various project teams to coordinate their activities. During a Scrum of Scrums (SoS) event, a representative from each scrum team meets on a regular basis to coordinate the activities among the various teams. When using Kanban, work is pulled from a prioritized backlog and processed through various stages of development through to completion. When using Kanban, work in progress (WIP) limits are set for each stage of work (represented by a column on the Kanban board) to expose bottlenecks and improve throughput. Projects are subject to three basic constraints, including time, cost, and scope (often referred to as the triple constraints). When using a predictive framework, the scope is fixed upfront, but the time and cost may vary. Even though time, cost, and scope are all baselined when using a predictive approach, it is highly unlikely that a project will finish exactly on time and budget, but the scope does not typically change. When using agile methods, the project scope is progressively elaborated rather than being defined upfront. A common concern when using agile practices is how to deal with situations in which the project or a deliverable has a fixed deadline and/or budget. Constraint-driven delivery provides a solution to this situation by holding time and/or cost fixed but allowing the scope to vary. When applying constraint-driven delivery, the desired features are captured and prioritized in a project backlog.
