answers.answer_text: Feature chart
Burndown chart
Burnup chart
Cumulative flow diagram

question_text: Which of the following might be listed in the project charter as a key deliverable?
explanation: All of the answer choices represent elements that may be included in the project charter. However, the question is asking which might be included as a key deliverable. A deliverable is any unique and verifiable product, result, or capability to perform a service that is required to be produced to complete a process, phase, or project. Of the choices provided, only a user manual meets the definition of a project deliverable, and therefore, is the best answer to the question asked. The PMBOK® Guide does not specifically mention a manual as a deliverable. We have provided the PMBOK® Guide as a general reference where a definition of a deliverable is given. Assuming that the PMP exam tests one's knowledge of the PMBOK® Guide is a common misconception. Although the PMBOK® Guide comprises the majority of the content you will encounter on the PMP exam, the PMP® Examination Content Outline assumes that aspirants are familiar with other sources that may be used by the Project Management Institute (PMI)® to develop their questions. Please refer to the PMI website for additional references: https://www.pmi.org/certifications/types/project-management-pmp/pmp-reference-list

answers.answer_text: A summary milestone schedule
A comprehensive user manual
Preapproved financial resources
A list of key project stakeholders

task: 3.2 Evaluate and deliver project benefits and value
question_text: You diligently gather all the available information about the project and produce a draft of the project charter, which you submit to the sponsor for approval. The following day the sponsor calls you and states that the charter is missing an essential element.
explanation: The business needs to be satisfied with the execution of the project are a significant component of the project charter and should always be included. Although each of the other answer choices is important to the successful completion of the project, none are available to be included in the project charter during the Initiating phase of a project.

answers.answer_text: The scope baseline for the project
The project schedule
A detailed project description including boundaries and all deliverables
The business needs to be satisfied with the execution of the project

task: 3.3 Evaluate and address external business environment changes for impact on scope
question_text: You are leading a project for a restaurant chain to reduce the average time a customer spends in the drive-through lanes. As part of the development of the project charter, you compare your company's drive-through processes to three competitors with the fastest drive-through lanes.
explanation: Benchmarking involves comparing your processes to those of comparable organizations considered to be 'best in class' and using the information to improve performance. Benchmarking is an example of a data-gathering technique that can be used as part of various project management processes, including Collect Requirements. In the scenario, you are managing a project to find reasons for your slower drive-through lane times and propose a solution. By comparing your company's drive-through lane processes to other fast food restaurants that have faster drive-through lanes, you can most likely find reasons for your slower drive-through lane times.

answers.answer_text: Brainstorming
Questionnaires
Focus groups
Benchmarking

question_text: A project is underway to build a prototype street sweeper. When viewing the dashboard of the prototype, the project manager sees a row of USB ports, which were not in the specifications. The engineer says that the ports were added because these days, everyone has a cell phone and would need USB connections.
explanation: The situation described by the question represents scope creep. Scope creep is the uncontrolled expansion to product or project scope without adjustments to time, cost, and resources. There may be valid reasons that USB ports are not in the specification, such as a rule that drivers should not use cell phones while working. Even though the USB ports have already been added, allowing them to remain will add risks to the project which have not been accounted for during risk planning. Therefore, of the available options, the best course of action for the project manager is to have the USB ports removed to keep the project in alignment with the approved scope baseline. Ideally, to ensure the USB port are (or are not) part of the scope, checking the relevant project documentation, such as the project scope statement, would be a better answer. However, this choice is not provided, forcing us to select the next 'best' one even if it does not look/sound like a perfect/ideal answer.

answers.answer_text: Nothing. The engineer is responsible for the details of the requirements.
Ensure that the verification team has procedures to test the USB ports
Tell the engineer that the USB ports should be removed
Use management reserves to cover the cost of adding the ports

question_text: As you prepare to gather requirements for a project you are leading, a review of the lessons learned repository suggests that improvements need to be made in the software development process.
explanation: The question suggests that the Collect Requirements process is being performed. Joint application design/development (JAD) sessions are used in the software development industry. These facilitated sessions focus on bringing business subject matter experts and the development team together to gather requirements and improve the software development process. To efficiently conduct the JAD sessions, the project manager should use their interpersonal and team skills such as facilitation which is among the tools and techniques of the Collect Requirements process. The incorrect answer choices represent actions that cannot be completed based on the sole authority of the project manager or would not affect the performance of the current project. Therefore, of the available options, scheduling a JAD session with the development team and subject matter experts is the best course of action.

answers.answer_text: Invite the development team to a project retrospective
Schedule a JAD session with the development team and subject matter experts
Review and update the requirements management plan as needed
Analyze the project business documents and modify as required

question_text: A project manager is leading a project to design and manufacture a new product. As part of the process to define and document the stakeholders' needs for the project, the project manager wants to determine the critical characteristics of the new product.
explanation: The question implies that the project manager is currently performing the Collect Requirements process. In the manufacturing industry, quality function deployment (QFD) is a facilitation technique that helps determine the critical characteristics for new product development. QFD starts by collecting customer needs, also known as the voice of the customer (VOC). These needs are then objectively sorted and prioritized, and goals are set for achieving them. Therefore, of the available choices, using quality function deployment (QFD) as a methodology to determine and prioritize customer requirements is the best response.

answers.answer_text: Invite software developers to a joint application design/development (JAD) session
Collect customer needs using the quality function deployment (QFD) technique
Analyze the project schedule network diagram and quality control measurements
Gather the customer requirements from the requirements traceability matrix

question_text: A project manager is in the process of defining and documenting stakeholders' needs for a software development project. The project manager feels that creating user stories might be particularly helpful in this process.
explanation: The question implies that the Collect Requirements process is being carried out with the defining and documenting stakeholders' needs. User stories, which are short, textual descriptions of required functionality, are often developed during a requirements workshop. User stories describe the stakeholder role, who benefits from the feature (role), what the stakeholder needs to accomplish (goal), and the benefit to the stakeholder (motivation). The incorrect answer choices represent activities that can only be performed after the requirements have been determined. Therefore, of the available options, scheduling a requirements workshop is the best response. Note, although the scenario suggests the project is managed using agile methodology where traditional project management processes may or may not be conducted as specified in the PMBOK® Guide, some of the answer choices and the explanations refer to the traditional approach. Regardless of this, scheduling a requirements workshop is still the best answer to the question asked.

answers.answer_text: Schedule a requirements workshop
Hold an iteration retrospective
Conduct a sprint review meeting
Develop a requirements traceability matrix

question_text: You are leading a meeting with a group of stakeholders to prioritize the product requirements for your project. After several rounds of voting, no prioritized ranking of product requirements attains more than 50% of the votes.
explanation: You, as the project manager, are using the decision-making technique of voting to determine a prioritized ranking of product requirements. Without being able to establish a majority for the requirements ranking, settling for a plurality may be the only viable option at this point. In the plurality decision-making technique, the largest voting block in the group decides even if a majority is not achieved. Permitting the plurality of voters to determine the prioritized ranking of product requirements will appease the greatest number of stakeholders participating in the meeting. Therefore, of the available options, the best course of action is to permit the plurality of voters to determine the ranking of product requirements.

answers.answer_text: Continue the meeting until unanimity can be reached
Allow the majority to determine the prioritization of the requirements
Permit the plurality of voters to prioritize the requirements
Use autocratic decision making to set the priority of the requirements

question_text: You are in the process of collecting detailed requirements for a user interface (UI) redesign project. Your stakeholders include business subject matter experts (SMEs) as well as the software development team. Both groups have vastly different ideas on product requirements, and the interactions between the groups become tense. You want to build trust, foster relationships, and achieve stakeholder consensus during requirements collection.
explanation: In this scenario, you have two groups of stakeholders who have a difference of opinion on the requirements of the redesigned UI, and yet you need to elicit requirements from them both. Facilitation is a technique that can be used in cross-functional workshops to define requirements and reconcile stakeholder differences. Well facilitated sessions can build trust, foster relationships, and improve communication among participants, which can lead to increased stakeholder consensus. While some of the answer choices provided are tools and techniques that can be used during the Collect Requirements process described in the question, under the circumstances presented, facilitation would be the best technique as it can assist with collecting requirements as well as build relationship among the stakeholders who have vastly different ideas on the product requirements.

answers.answer_text: Decision tree analysis
Facilitation
Multicriteria decision analysis
Mind mapping

question_text: A new project was chartered. As the project manager, you meet with some of the pre-assigned team members to look over the problems the project seeks to address. The project team feels the requirements provided are vague and unclear.
explanation: Understanding the needs, wants, expectations, and requirements is extremely important for the project team to plan and manage the project to address those needs appropriately. The one best qualified to express those needs is the customer, or a suitable customer representative or business analyst. One of the answer choices mentions the customer. Clarifying the requirements and gaining more definition from the customer allows the project team to better fulfill those requirements. Including suitable members of the team eliminates misinterpretation and unanswered questions. Educating more of the team on the needs and the problems to solve enables the project team to better comprehend the requirements and customer needs.

answers.answer_text: Assign accountability of the various requirements to each project team member
Facilitate a benchmarking session to collect more detailed requirements
Facilitate a discussion meeting between the project team and the customer
Take responsibility as project manager to rewrite the requirements with more clarity

task: 2.13 Determine appropriate project methodology/methods and practices
question_text: Your company was awarded a software development project. You have just drafted the scope management plan and submitted it to the sponsor for her initial review. The sponsor reviews the plan and states that the client specified the use of Scrum, while according to the plan, the scope will be delivered using waterfall project management practices.
explanation: The scope management plan is created as an output of the Plan Scope Management process. The question indicates that the project requirements specified by the client included the use of Scrum as a development methodology, while the scope management plan reflects a waterfall framework. The components of the project management plan that may serve as inputs into the Plan Scope Management process typically include the quality management plan, project life cycle description, and development approach. The development approach defines whether waterfall, iterative, adaptive, agile, or a hybrid development approach will be used on the project. Scrum is an example of an agile methodology. Therefore, according to the scenario, it is reasonable to assume that the development approach indicated in the project management plan mistakenly called for waterfall instead of Scrum. Hence, the development approach is the component of the project management plan that should be corrected.

answers.answer_text: Project life cycle description
Development approach
Requirements management plan
The contract with the client

task: 2.13 Determine appropriate project methodology/methods and practices
question_text: A project has been chartered with so many unknowns and little clarity as to how the products are to be built and designed even though it is extremely clear to all that something has to be done and fast.
explanation: Defining project and product scope can be accomplished in many different ways depending on the needs of the project and other circumstances. The circumstances in this scenario are that there is a time sensitivity but lots of unknowns. Without clear knowledge of what needs to be done and how, deciding as a team all that needs to be done before started is difficult. Attempting to fully define the project work before starting work may be more time consuming compared to starting with a roadmap and some less clear requirements. Building off lesser requirements and gathering feedback and input provides fodder for the stakeholders to work from and define the scope further. This agile approach to project management enables stakeholders to progressively elaborate the project's outcomes and plans to achieve those outcomes.

answers.answer_text: Ensure all stakeholders are in agreement on the product and project scope at the start, then progress towards one solution
Establish an evolving product roadmap, then define and refine the scope as the project progresses
Stabilize the primary project requirements before any project team members are acquired
Create a program of different projects to see which one works best

question_text: The project team has worked for months on an open-ended concept product for their organization. Some team members are ready to push it out to users to get feedback. Others are not sure.
explanation: Performing the Validate Scope process requires some decisions as to whether the scope is, in fact, complete and acceptable. There are many tools and techniques a project manager can use with stakeholders to make decisions. In this scenario, the stakeholders involved in validating the scope are members of the project team. As such, there is some interpretation as to whether the project that delivers on an open-ended concept product may or may not have clear directives and well-documented scope and requirements. The decision making requires more input and consultation with those involved. Before any decision is made, it is advisable to concern all inputs, perspectives, and arguments. After an appropriate time to discuss those inputs relative to the project and its timeline, a more informed decision can be made.

answers.answer_text: Release the product then ask the team to validate scope
Consider the options then go with what feels right
Hear the competing arguments then ask all to vote
Refer to the stakeholder register then decide

question_text: As a team facilitator, you are leading an agile software development project. During the daily standup meeting, a development team member states that they need clarification with an element of the user interface and cannot move forward without the feedback.
explanation: In this scenario, you, as the team facilitator of an agile team, are leading a daily standup meeting. One of the elements of the daily standup is raising any impediments facing the development team. The team facilitator, as a servant leader, should ensure that impediments are removed as quickly as possible while adhering to agile best practices. In agile, the product owner serves as the voice of the customer and is responsible for guiding the direction of the product. Therefore, in this scenario, the team facilitator should engage the product owner or refer the team member to the product owner to obtain the necessary feedback so the team member can continue developing the product increment.

answers.answer_text: Tell the team member to query relevant stakeholders
Refer the team member to the product owner
Advise the team member to wait until the sprint review
Provide the team member with your understanding of the requirements

question_text: Gold plating had been a recurring issue on your project as the team has been adding features they think are useful for the customer even though the features were not included in the WBS. Change requests have been submitted after the fact, and some of the features were eventually added to the project scope. You are concerned about deviations from the plan.
explanation: The scenario describes a situation where project team members have been adding features not included in the planned scope. The team members think these features are interesting and useful for the customer. This practice is known as gold plating. The question also states that the project has a work breakdown structure (WBS) and baselines, which implies that a traditional waterfall framework is being employed for this project. A daily standup meeting is a common ceremony used on agile projects, but can also be incorporated into a predictive model. One of the objectives of a daily standup meeting is for each team member to identify what they plan to accomplish during the next 24-hour period. If the project manager can gain an understanding of the work planned for the day, they can address any deviations from the planned work beforehand. Of the available answer choices, instituting a daily standup meeting has the best probability of eliminating, or at least reducing, the gold plating.

answers.answer_text: Adopt an agile approach so the team can develop any features they deem valuable
Submit a change request to capture the gold plating problem in the issue log
Discuss the issue at the project retrospective and update the lessons learned register
Incorporate the agile practice of holding daily standup meetings with the team

question_text: A manufacturer of medical devices has just initiated a new project for a client. The project is similar to past projects performed by the company, with most of the project constraints, such as cost, schedule, quality, and risks being known upfront. The scope, however, is not clearly defined since the client is new to the market and cannot provide detailed specifications.
explanation: According to the scenario, most of the project constraints are known upfront, and the organization is experienced in this type of project, implying the project can be predominantly lead using the predictive project management approach. However, with the scope that cannot be defined upfront, the pure predictive approach is unlikely to work. Under these circumstances, introducing some agile elements into the scope management portion of the project may help in reducing the uncertainty. For example, instead of spending time trying to define and agree on scope early in project initiation and planning, the project team would be better off focusing on establishing the process for the ongoing discovery and refinement of the scope. Such an approach would make the project a hybrid, allowing the performing organization and the client to benefit from the best of both worlds - the certainty of the predictive planning for stable project elements and flexibility of agile for those that are less certain.

answers.answer_text: Working with the client during early project planning to get as detailed specifications as possible
Establishing the process for ongoing discovery and refinement of the scope and specifications
Reporting the status of the known project constraints, such as cost, schedule, quality, risks
Categorizing project stakeholders using the stakeholder engagement assessment matrix

question_text: Since project execution began, the project has been experiencing a high volume of new features, change requests, and defect repairs. The project manager has a difficult time managing and controlling project work, performing change control, and validating scope.
explanation: The way the scenario is framed implies that while a predictive project management approach has been selected for the project, the environment in which the project operates suggests that agile or, at least, hybrid methods would have been more appropriate for the project manager to use. Switching the project management approach midway into project execution is not always feasible or advisable. However, unless stated otherwise in the scenario, the project manager, in consultation with the team and relevant stakeholders, is free to choose any approach that would work better than the one currently employed. When agile practices are incorporated into a traditionally managed project, the approach becomes hybrid. With agile methods, various work streams, such as new features, change requests, defect repairs are typically combined into a single backlog that can be reprioritized and managed as a single-list-of-work-and-changes artifact. This approach would provide the project manager and stakeholders an easier way to manage and control project work, perform change control, and validate scope.

answers.answer_text: Use management reserves to cover the costs associated with managing these unknown unknowns
Hire additional team members and assign each new team member a process to manage
Limit the number of new features, change requests, and defect repairs allowed on the project
Combine the new features, change requests, and defect repairs into a single backlog

question_text: The scrum master, business analyst, programmers, and testers have been assigned to a product development project. The performing organization is well-versed with the traditional waterfall framework but will incorporate scrum for the software development phase of the project.
explanation: The roles typically associated with scrum include the scrum master, development team, and product owner. In this scenario, the product owner is the role that is vacant. Although the business analyst is a role that is typically associated with waterfall projects, the business analyst can also provide support to the team leader and product owner in an agile environment. The business analyst typically works with the customer to determine and refine project requirements and develop the requirements documentation. When agile methodologies are employed, the business analyst may also assist with the development and refinement of the product backlog. With scrum, the product owner is responsible for managing the product backlog and ensuring that it is prioritized according to business value. In this case, the business analyst will likely have much of the necessary skill set to serve as the product owner but will be lacking in knowledge and experience with agile. Thus, the scrum master should mentor the business analyst to close any agile knowledge gaps and ensure that all of the duties related to a product owner are fulfilled.

answers.answer_text: Remove the business analyst from the software development phase since that role is only associated with waterfall project management
Mentor the business analyst to serve in the role of the product owner during the software development phase since those roles are closely aligned
Request that one of the programmers serve as the voice-of-the-customer for the purposes of prioritizing the items in the product backlog
Ask the most experienced tester to approve or reject the deliverables during the sprint review as testers are typically most familiar with the product

question_text: Collecting requirements for the project and creating the WBS has been a daunting task because stakeholders' needs are vague and are only expressed in the most general terms due to the nature of the project. As a result of this uncertainty, the project manager is concerned about excessive changes, wasted work, and rework anticipated during project execution.
explanation: The scenario describes a situation where, due to the nature of the project, the requirements are not clearly understood and can only be expressed at a high level. This situation presents an obstacle to collecting project requirements and creating a fully decomposed work breakdown structure (WBS) as part of initial project planning. Projects with a high level of uncertainty in requirements benefit from iterative and incremental approaches that allow the project scope to evolve over the course of the project. Demonstrating smaller increments of the product to the relevant stakeholders allows for short feedback loops to keep the evolving product or result of the project in alignment with stakeholder needs and expectations. For example, the project team might use prototypes to gain early feedback on the requirements. All of the incorrect answer choices represent strategies that would be unrealistic for a project with a high degree of uncertainty in the project requirements. Note that incorporating an agile lifecycle within a project management plan would make this a hybrid project.

answers.answer_text: Develop a project scope statement and decompose it down to the work package level as part of initial project planning
Request that the project team use an iterative and incremental approach to product development with short feedback loops
Implement a robust change control system to only allow for the most important changes to be incorporated into the product
Generate an activity list from what is currently known and use the Kanban board to break the activities down to their tasks

question_text: A project manager is implementing the requirements management plan for a software upgrade project that will incorporate some agile elements. The project manager needs to quickly define cross-functional requirements and reconcile stakeholder differences to build a consensus among the relevant stakeholders.
explanation: The question implies that the project manager is carrying out the Collect Requirements process for a hybrid project. Workshops can be used to quickly define cross-functional requirements and reconcile stakeholder differences. The interactive nature of a workshop can be effective in helping the project manager build a consensus among the stakeholders. When agile methodologies are being incorporated into a project, a requirements gathering workshop may take the form of a story-writing workshop, where required functionality is captured in the form of a user story. Of the available choices, only a requirements workshop would meet the project manager's criteria for being able to 'quickly' gather feedback, and have the interactivity necessary to reconcile stakeholder differences and help build a consensus.

answers.answer_text: Create a questionnaire and send it out to all of the stakeholders to determine the project requirements
Conduct an in-person interview with each of the relevant stakeholders to determine their needs
Facilitate a requirements workshop with all of the relevant stakeholders to develop user stories
Perform a job shadowing exercise with the intended end-users of the existing software

question_text: To collect requirements for the new software application, a product owner facilitates a meeting with developers, customer representatives, and other stakeholders. The participants create short, textual descriptions of the required functionality, indicate those who will benefit from the feature, as well as the goal of and the motivation behind the functionality.
explanation: The scenario describes the Collect Requirements process. Facilitating a meeting is an example of the interpersonal and team skills that can be used as one of the tools and techniques associated with this process. A story-writing workshop is a meeting that includes developers, customer representatives, end-users, and other stakeholders who can contribute to writing the user stories. During the workshop, the participants write as many user stories as they can. No priorities are associated with the user stories at this point because the customer will have a chance to do that later. While the initial user stories are often written during a user story workshop, stories can be written at any time throughout the project.

answers.answer_text: Kick-off meeting
User story workshop
Sprint planning meeting
Backlog grooming workshop

task: 2.1 Execute project with the urgency required to deliver business value
question_text: A company considers a project to develop a new mobile app. Since it's unclear how target users will adopt the app, the company decides to develop an early release of the app incrementally with only the must-have features, and then, if feedback from the users is positive, proceed with the full-featured app using a predictive project management approach.
explanation: The scenario describes a hybrid project that will be accomplished in two phases: an early release of the product to the target end-users, a product that will be developed incrementally using agile practices, and a second phase that will be conducted using the predictive project management approach. A minimum viable product (MVP) is a powerful concept that allows organizations to test their ideas. The initial development effort for an MVP concentrates solely on those features absolutely necessary for successful deployment of the product. Once this initial product is developed, it is exposed to a subset of the target users to collect relevant data about the product to determine if it is 'viable' and if the company should move forward with the full-blown development of the product. Since the lack of knowledge, uncertainty, and risk are closely related, the MVP is often viewed as a risk reduction tool.

answers.answer_text: Agile release planning
Minimum viable product
Fully functioning prototype
Work breakdown structure

question_text: The product owner meets with the project team members to discuss the user stories for the next iteration. The product owner points out the user stories that hold the highest value, while the team indicates which user stories bear the highest risk. By the end of the meeting, the user stories in the iteration backlog are prioritized, and the team knows how to develop them.
explanation: Discussing the value of the user stories and the risk associated with them, eventually resulting in a prioritized backlog, can be best described by backlog refinement. Backlog refinement is the progressive elaboration of project requirements (user stories) in which the team and relevant stakeholders, such as the product owner, collaboratively review and update the requirements to satisfy customer needs. An iteration backlog is typically prioritized based on the value a user story represents for the customer combined with the risk associated with the user story. An outcome is a prioritized iteration backlog. As the work progresses, the product owner, together with the team, works with the stakeholders to prioritize the product backlog, identify new items, refine existing items, and clean up items that are no longer needed. This process is called backlog refinement and must be performed continuously throughout the project. Backlog refinement is also referred to as backlog grooming.

answers.answer_text: Develop Schedule
Kano analysis
Backlog refinement
Risk assessment

question_text: To create initial user stories, the product owner is facilitating a story writing workshop with the team and project stakeholders.
explanation: An agile project’s initial user stories are often written in a story writing workshop, but user stories can be written at any time throughout the project. During the story writing workshop, everyone brainstorms as many stories as possible. Armed with a starting set of stories, the developers estimate the size of each. During a story writing workshop, the focus should be on quantity rather than quality, so attendees should write as many user stories within the prescribed timebox of the workshop.

answers.answer_text: To create as many user stories as possible
To create user stories for the first iteration
To refine user stories in the product backlog
To re-prioritize user stories for the first release

task: 2.1 Execute project with the urgency required to deliver business value
question_text: An XP development team discusses the size of the software release to be delivered in each iteration by their new project.
explanation: One of the XP core practices is to deliver software in small releases. Small releases allow the team to get feedback from the customer and the stakeholders sooner, thus reducing the risk of building the wrong thing for too long. As stated by the author in the reference, "Delivering small, frequent, high-quality releases builds more trust with partner teams than putting larger release less often. Small releases show that the software development team can deliver and is committed to providing value."

answers.answer_text: Deliver small releases to demonstrate progress to the customer and stakeholders
Deliver large releases to provide as much value to the customer as possible in one iteration
For small projects deliver small releases, for big projects use large ones
For small teams deliver small releases, for large teams use large ones

question_text: An agile team has just finished an iteration in which one of the user stories is only partially complete.
explanation: Velocity represents the rate of completion rather than the time or effort expended. Therefore, incomplete user stories are excluded from velocity values at the end of the iteration. Customers are only interested in receiving completed user stories and see no value in incomplete work, regardless of how much of the user story was completed. For example, a partially complete product feature cannot be used to generate revenue for the customer. The incomplete user story should be returned to the product backlog at the end of the iteration. The product owner will then reprioritize the backlog and determine where to rank the incomplete user story for the next iteration.

answers.answer_text: The project team must finish the development of the incomplete user story during the upcoming iteration.
The number of story points of the incomplete user story should be excluded from the current iteration.
The partially completed user story should be approved since it represents partial value for the customer.
Velocity estimates for the upcoming iterations should take into account the incomplete user story.

question_text: Which factors should be considered while prioritizing items in the product backlog?
explanation: There are several factors that should be considered while prioritizing items in the product backlog. It is easier to think of a backlog item as a user story. What value would the user story bring to the customer after it is delivered? How much will it cost, or what is the effort required to create the user story? What is the risk associated with the development of the user story? All those are among the factors that contribute to how the backlog items should be prioritized.

answers.answer_text: Risk, cost, value
Risk, cost, priority
NPV, ROI, IRR
Mad, sad, glad

question_text: After a few successful iterations, agile team members hold a planning meeting for their next sprint.
explanation: During the sprint planning meeting, a determination is made regarding what will be delivered during the upcoming sprint and how the work will be achieved. The product owner presents the updated backlog items, and the team forecasts what can be delivered during the sprint as the product owner and the team members define the sprint goal. The team then determines how the product increment will be built and how they will organize themselves to deliver the sprint goal. Of the available options, a list of work items to be completed in the next sprint best addresses the outcome of the meeting described in the scenario, making that list the best answer to the question asked.

answers.answer_text: A working product increment
An activity list and a project schedule network diagram
A prioritized list of product backlog items
A list of work items to be completed in the next sprint

question_text: While working on the screen layout of a mobile application, a developer on an agile team came up with a screen improvement idea that will enhance the application's usability, and ultimately increase customer satisfaction. Implementing this idea represents a new requirement. The developer's first thought is to implement this improvement to impress their client.
explanation: If the developer has a suggested improvement in mind that can potentially benefit the end-user experience when using the application, the next step should be to suggest this idea to the product owner for possible inclusion in one of the upcoming iterations. The product owner can then review the requirement, create a user story, and present it to the customer. If it is agreed that the idea for the new requirement has merit by both the product owner and the customer, it can then be placed in the product backlog and prioritized. Implementing the requirement without presenting it to the product owner first may be considered gold plating. Gold plating occurs when a developer adds features to the product that were not part of the original requirements. Gold plating is not an agile best practice or a good practice for any project.

answers.answer_text: Implement the improvement and demonstrate the new screen layout to the product owner
Do nothing since this requirement is out of scope and it should not be added to the product.
Suggest the improvement to the product owner for possible inclusion in the upcoming iterations
Reach out to the customer and obtain their approval to implement the suggested improvement

task: 2.1 Execute project with the urgency required to deliver business value
question_text: Which of the following is the best course of action for a development team to maximize the value delivered to the customer?
explanation: User stories may be sliced into smaller chunks or resized. This action means breaking down any stories that are too large to be completed within one iteration. By slicing the stories, the development team ensures that instead of having the customer wait for a big user story to be completed later in the project, the value can be delivered by completing smaller user stories in each iteration.

answers.answer_text: Cancel the iteration due to changes in technology
Change the length of an iteration
Split user stories in the iteration backlog
Reprioritize the product backlog

task: 2.1 Execute project with the urgency required to deliver business value
question_text: The Agile Manifesto's 4 values and 12 principles form the foundation of all agile methods. Although all of these values and principles are critical to the success of any agile project, one principle stands out as the top priority for all agile projects.
explanation: In 2001, a group of 17 software developers practicing various agile methods met to compare notes and determine the commonalities between these different agile methods. The result was the first draft of The Agile Manifesto for Software Development, which presented these common organizing principles in a single document. The Agile Manifesto is based on 4 values and 12 principles that help guide agile project teams when executing their projects. Agile Manifesto Principle # 1 states, “Our highest priority is to satisfy the customer through early and continuous delivery of valuable software.” This principle underscores the focus of delivering value to the customer, and it is this philosophy of customer satisfaction that drives agile project teams. Note: You may have noticed that the word 'product' was substituted for the word 'software' in the question and answer choices. This word choice is because although the original drafters of the Agile Manifesto were talking about these values and principles supporting 'software' development, it is now understood that these principles can be successfully applied to any type of 'product' development. It is very important that you fully understand the Agile Manifesto values and principles because they help form the foundation of all agile project management activities.

answers.answer_text: Delivering working product frequently, from a couple of weeks to a couple of months
Welcoming changing requirements, even late in development
Satisfying the customer through early and continuous delivery of valuable product
Building projects around motivated individuals

task: 2.1 Execute project with the urgency required to deliver business value
question_text: An agile team is developing custom manufacturing equipment for a client. After three iterations, a functional prototype is ready, but it lacks critical safety features as well as several enhancements that can be installed on-site in future releases. To get early feedback from the client, the product owner requests that the team deliver an MVP as soon as possible.
explanation: A minimum viable product (MVP) is the smallest set of tested and consumer-ready functionality that provides value to either internal users or external customers. In this scenario, the prototype lacks critical safety features, which means that it is not consumer-ready. It would be irresponsible, as well as a violation of the PMI Code of Ethics, to release equipment to a customer that might be dangerous due to the lack of safety features. Although an MVP may include only limited features, safety features would be required to meet the criteria as an MVP. Therefore, in this case, the project manager should ensure that all safety features are installed and working properly to meet the criteria as an MVP and then deliver the equipment to the client.

answers.answer_text: Install safety features and enhancements on the prototype and deliver it to the client
Install the safety features only on the prototype and deliver it to the client
Deliver the prototype to the client in its current condition as it is already functional
Install the enhancements only on the prototype and deliver it to the client

task: 2.1 Execute project with the urgency required to deliver business value
question_text: An agile team is working on a new software application for an online purchasing system. The product owner has instructed the team to prioritize the development of the features based on their net present value (NPV).
explanation: This was a bit tricky question because we included the investment amount to throw you off. NPV compares the value of a dollar today to the value of that same dollar in the future. The investment amount is already taken into account when NPV is calculated. NPV is a measure of how much money a feature can be expected to return in today’s present value. When selecting the order of features to develop on an agile project using NPV, simply calculate the NPV for each feature and then select the feature with the highest NPV. In this situation, the network upgrade feature has an NPV of $175,000, which is the highest NPV of all these features, and should therefore be developed first. Please note that in traditional project management NPV is mainly used to select 'projects', which is also the case in agile project management. However, agile projects can take NPV a bit further by using it to determine the order in which 'features' (also referred to as 'themes' or 'capabilities') should be developed, as is the case in this situation.

answers.answer_text: A customer relationship management feature that has an investment of $900,000 and NPV of $87,500
A website interface feature that has an investment of $500,000 and NPV of $100,000
A network upgrade feature that has an investment of $750,000 and NPV of $175,000
A data warehouse feature that has an investment of $1,000,000 and NPV of $50,000

task: 2.1 Execute project with the urgency required to deliver business value
question_text: An organization has a planning cycle, where they approve their budgets and project hiring requirements annually. Senior executives want to implement agile principles and methodology in their product development and rollout.
explanation: According to Shalloway, "annual planning cycles result in longer-than-necessary projects. In addition, failing to focus on Minimum Marketable Features results in larger-than-necessary projects, which take longer to complete." They argue that with long annual planning cycles, features take a long time to go through the steps of waiting to be planned, planning and completing. The organization can still gain significant business value when they plan and prioritize based on minimal marketable features.

answers.answer_text: Plan resourcing around individuals rather than teams
Approve and prioritize features annually
Focus on minimal marketable features
Inspect and adapt annually

task: 3.3 Evaluate and address external business environment changes for impact on scope
question_text: After three iterations, a demo version of a new mobile app is demonstrated to end-users. The users complain that the app's security features are too complicated and would deter them from using it. The project manager realizes that modifications to the security features will require substantial rework that was not accounted for during risk identification and planning.
explanation: The scenario suggests that the development of the application is carried out using agile practices while some other aspects of the project are conducted using the traditional project management approach as implied by risk identification and planning. Agile teams should verify and validate the value of what they are delivering. Changes are welcomed in Agile, even late in development. However, when traditional project elements are involved, changes should follow the established organization's change control process. The problem described in the scenario should be addressed using a hybrid approach. One aspect is submitting a change request to evaluate the impact of the changes on all project constraints. It is likely that additional funds will be required to cover the unknown costs of the rework. Another aspect is to request the product owner to refine the product backlog, specifically the user stories related to the security features. The product owner will then need to instruct the team on the modifications that should be made. Therefore, of the choices provided, the combined response of submitting a change request and asking the product owner to refine the product backlog is likely to be the best answer to the question asked.

answers.answer_text: Instruct the team to modify security features to make the application more user-friendly
Suggest that the team proceed with the development according to the original plan
Submit a change request and ask the product owner to refine the product backlog
Cease all project work to avoid any further damage to the company's reputation

question_text: All of the following are true about how user stories should be prioritized and delivered except for?
explanation: The product owner typically sets the overall priority among the different user stories before the start of an iteration. The product owner can more easily perform this prioritization when the user stories are independent. Another consideration is a holistic relative prioritization of requirements based on the aspects such as financial benefits, costs, risk, innovation, and knowledge or customer value associated with each user story. Further conversations among the project stakeholders about user stories occur during iteration planning, such that the order set by the product owner at the beginning of the project may not be how the user stories are eventually developed and delivered. For example, after further deliberation with the team, priorities may change. Some potential reasons for such re-prioritization include the ability of the team to deliver the complete user story within an iteration, the desire to group related work, the need to mitigate a risk sooner, and so on.

answers.answer_text: User stories are prioritized based on financial benefits, costs, risk, innovation, and knowledge.
Prioritization would be easier if user stories are independent of one another.
Prioritization of user stories can be altered in between iterations.
User stories are delivered based on the order set by the product owner in the beginning of the project.

task: 2.1 Execute project with the urgency required to deliver business value
question_text: A company wants to be first to market with its new product. A stakeholder who is unfamiliar with agile methods does not understand why the initial release of the product is to include only a few basic features.
explanation: Creating an initial release that provides just those features that make the product viable, valuable, and useful is referred to as a minimal viable product, minimum viable product, or MVP. An MVP is a product release that is complete enough to be useful to the customers or the market, but is a subset of the project's objectives. Such an incremental release can allow a company to establish a market presence, allow for some immediate return on investment, and can be further elaborated in subsequent releases. An MVP also allows for early customer feedback to build additional high-value features in subsequent product increments and, at the same time, avoid building unnecessary features that are not valued by the customer. Building in additional high-value features in subsequent product increments is a foundational best practice of agile. According to Eric Reis, "The minimum viable product is that version of a new product a team uses to collect the maximum amount of validated learning about customers with the least effort."

answers.answer_text: In a basic product the defects are kept to a minimum
Keeping the product simple would reduce technical debt
Building a few basic features would avoid team burnout
A basic release provides the customer with a valuable MVP

question_text: An agile team is developing a product for a customer. In the last few iterations, the team members spent extra hours creating product documentation and reviewing the contracts with the customer.
explanation: To answer this question correctly, one should be familiar with the Agile Manifesto values. Overemphasis on creating product documentation runs contrary to the value of "Working software over comprehensive documentation". Reviewing the contract with the customer runs contrary to the value of "Customer collaboration over contract negotiation". Neither of these activities represents value to the customer. Creating the product increment corresponds to "working software"; working with the product owner represents "customer collaboration". Therefore, based on Agile values, the team members' time is better spent creating the product increment and working with the product owner rather than creating product documentation and reviewing the contract with the customer.

answers.answer_text: Reporting the extra hours in the company's time and attendance tools
Building features according to the initial project management plan
Creating the product increment and working with the product owner
Developing functionality as requested by the project sponsor

question_text: At the iteration review meeting, several stakeholders are confused and concerned with the software being demonstrated as it does not represent their expectations or priorities.
explanation: The situation presented in this question implies that the prioritization and/or the description or communication of the user stories to the development team was inaccurate and did not convey the true needs of the customer. The business needs of the customer change over time and one of the strengths of agile is that these changing requirements can be reflected quickly in a properly groomed product backlog. In this instance, the confusion and concern expressed by the stakeholders at the iteration review are reflective of a product backlog that did not reflect the customers' needs or expectations. Grooming the backlog to reflect the needs and expectations of the customers and stakeholders is the responsibility of the product owner.

answers.answer_text: The stakeholders not attending the daily standup meetings
The product owner not properly grooming the product backlog
The team not properly defining when a user story is done
The product owner not adequately defining the acceptance criteria

question_text: Agile team members are arguing about backlog prioritization.
explanation: The scenario refers to Scope Management as it applies to agile projects. The agile project management approach is typically selected for projects with unclear upfront requirements and that are often changed as the project progresses. Agile methods spend less time trying to define scope early in project planning. Rather, agile projects utilize a product backlog with the requirements (user stories) prioritized based on specific criteria, such as value for the customer, risk, etc. Before each iteration, the product owner, team, and relevant stakeholders refine the product backlog. As a result, the scope is defined and redefined throughout the project. Prioritization is a step in grooming the backlog, which happens throughout the life of the project.

answers.answer_text: Stop the conflict immediately as conflict is bad for team performance
Indicate that prioritization is an ongoing process throughout the project
Tell the team that prioritization is only the customer's responsibility
Allow the team members to define the priority of the user stories

question_text: A construction project is in planning and will utilize a predictive project management approach. The nature of the project allows for the project scope to be fully decomposed. The project manager begins to create the WBS.
explanation: The question is asking for the components that may comprise the work breakdown structure (WBS). The WBS is a hierarchical decomposition of the total scope of work to be carried out by the project team to accomplish the project objectives and create the required deliverables. The WBS may contain control accounts, planning packages, and work packages. The correct responses represent the definitions for a control account, planning package, and work package, and each of these would be considered elements of the WBS. The incorrect responses are project artifacts that exist outside of the WBS.

answers.answer_text: A point where scope, budget, cost, and schedule are integrated and compared to earned value for performance measurement
A component below the control account with known work content but without detailed schedule activities
A documented tabulation of schedule activities that shows their description, identifier, and scope of the work
The work defined at the lowest level for which cost and duration are estimated and managed
A description of the project scope, major deliverables, and exclusions
A depiction of linked activities with planned dates, durations, milestones, and resources

task: 3.2 Evaluate and deliver project benefits and value
question_text: An agile project is underway when the budget is drastically reduced. As a result, the team will not be able to complete the project backlog.
explanation: Project teams need to focus on delivering business value. All projects operate within the constraints of time, cost, and scope. In the scenario described, the project budget has been drastically cut, and the project team will not be able to complete the project scope as originally planned. However, it still might be possible for the project team to deliver some business value even with the reduced budget. The first logical action for the agile leader will be to collaborate with the development team, product owner, and any other relevant stakeholders to review the project backlog to determine what, if any, business value can still be delivered. If yes, the project should proceed with the adjusted backlog. If it is determined that the cost constraint is such that no additional business value can be delivered, then the project will likely need to be terminated so the resources can be redeployed. However, reviewing the project backlog with the development team and product owner would be the first course of action for the project leader, as asked by the question.

answers.answer_text: Reduce the size of the project team to cut cost
Terminate the project so the assets can be redeployed
Review the project backlog with the development team and product owner
Compress the schedule by applying the technique referred to as crashing

task: 3.2 Evaluate and deliver project benefits and value
question_text: A project is being initiated to transition a manufacturing plant to be more environmentally friendly. Since the project requirements are vague, an agile development approach has been selected. The return on investment (ROI) is expected to be negative, and the performing organization is aware of and accepts this fact.
explanation: Project teams should focus on delivering business value. Many traditionally think of business value in financial terms. However, projects are initiated for a variety of reasons, some of which might not be financial. In the scenario described, the performing organization is aware of and accepts that the ROI is negative. Therefore, it is reasonable to assume that while there will likely be some financial constraints, the intended benefit of the project is not financial but rather the delivery of a public good. Specifically, the project is intended to lessen the negative environmental impact of the manufacturing process. Since the requirements are vague and ambiguous, the project team will need to understand the project's intended benefits, so the work remains in alignment with the project goals. The business case should outline the business need, project justification, and business strategy. This information will be essential in helping the project team understand the reason for the project to be initiated in the first place and the project's intended benefits.

answers.answer_text: Request the team members to volunteer some of their time to compensate for the negative ROI
Empower the team to operate in the adjourning stage of the Tuckman ladder
Develop a detailed work breakdown structure (WBS) based on the known requirements
Review the project's business case with the team to understand the intended benefits

question_text: During an iteration review, the customer requests a change to the product that will enable it to connect with and send/receive data to/from external systems rather than relying solely on user inputs. The change will significantly increase the project's complexity and add unknown risks related to interconnection with those external systems.
explanation: Project leaders need to continually evaluate and navigate project complexity. Complexity can emerge at any point in a project. The scenario describes a project, likely agile or hybrid, as evident by the iteration review, where the customer requests a change that will require the product to interface and communicate with other systems. The change will increase the complexity of the project and introduce unknown interconnection risks. Knowledge of systems thinking and interaction between systems may help the project team navigate the increased complexity of the project. If the team members lack this knowledge, they may need to acquire it as the project unfolds. This continuous learning related to system interaction will improve the team's ability to navigate the emerging complexity.

answers.answer_text: An increased iteration length
Better customer collaboration
A larger project team size
Knowledge of system interactions

question_text: A project team has been tasked with developing a new product. However, due to the new technology required for its development, the company wants the team to dedicate the first sprint for experimentation before committing resources in full. At the sprint planning meeting, stakeholders offer several ideas as design concepts.
explanation: Project leaders need to embrace adaptability and resiliency to improve project outcomes. Adaptability refers to the ability to respond to changing conditions, while resiliency is the ability to absorb impacts and recover quickly from a setback or failure. One strategy that can improve adaptability and resiliency is the use of small-scale prototypes and experiments to test ideas. In the scenario provided, several design concepts have been suggested. In order to best evaluate each of the design concepts, a small-scale prototype can be developed for each at a reduced cost. Demonstrating the prototypes will allow the relevant stakeholders to provide their insights and feedback to select and better refine the design that will deliver the most business value. Getting locked into a particular design early will increase the risk of rework and disappointment in the final product. Delaying the selection decision until the project team is confident in the best design will improve adaptability and resiliency for the project.

answers.answer_text: Develop the riskiest design concept first so the project can fail fast
Demonstrate small-scale prototypes during a sprint review to test the ideas
Select the design idea of the stakeholder with the most power and influence
Create a story map for the features comprising the backlog of the first sprint

question_text: A project backlog comprised of various user stories. Some represent unique and risky features, while others cover routine work activities.
explanation: From the way the scenario is phrased, one may infer that an agile/adaptive project is in its early stages. The project backlog consists of various user stories and work items. A backlog of a typical agile project is prioritized by the customer (or its representative) based on the business value. However, other criteria can play a role in how the backlog is prioritized. For example, user stories that represent unique, significant, risky, or novel work can be prioritized and put at the top of the backlog over items that cover routine tasks. The latter can be planned based on the concept of the last responsible moment. The last responsible moment is the approach in which the project team considers multiple options and defers the decision on when the routine items should be completed (if at all) until the cost of further delay exceeds the benefit. This strategy reduces waste by not spending time in developing plans for work that may change or may not be needed altogether.

answers.answer_text: Prioritized at the top of each sprint backlog
Deferred until the last responsible moment
Decomposed into WBS work packages
Removed from the sprint and project backlogs

question_text: A project does not have clearly defined requirements up front. To evolve the requirements as the project unfolds, the team will build prototypes, create storyboards and mock-ups, and hold demonstrations for relevant stakeholders.
explanation: The scenario describes a project that does not have clearly defined requirements up front. Such projects are typically carried out using the adaptive development approach with the product created incrementally and iteratively. Ideally, each consecutive iteration results in a working product increment. However, when requirements are vague or unknown, such as is the case in the scenario, the project team evolves requirements by building prototypes, creating storyboards and mock-ups, and holding demonstrations for relevant stakeholders. While demonstrated to the stakeholders, the product may rigger new ideas in their heads that, in turn, may result in the identification of new requirements. This requirement-gathering method is often referred to as the "I'll know it when I see it" approach. In other words, instead of defining requirements first and then building the product to cover the requirements, a very basic version of the product is created first (a mockup, wireframe, prototype), and then new requirements are determined. Note, under the circumstances described in the scenario, an adaptive development approach is the most logical choice for the team to select to carry out the project work. However, the question asks about the approach to evolving requirements that project stakeholders, not the project team members, are likely to take. Carefully reading the scenario and the question statement is crucial to selecting the correct answer.

answers.answer_text: Adaptive development approach
Hands-on and top-down approach
Caves and common approach
"I'll know it when I see it" approach

question_text: At the sprint planning meeting, a project team works with the product owner to elaborate scope. After identifying themes, the meeting attendees define epics. However, the epics are too big to be developed within one sprint. The product owner suggests decomposing the epics into features.
explanation: The scenario describes a sprint planning meeting and implies that the project team and product owner are decomposing the project scope. Scope decomposition on an agile project, like the one suggested by the question, is different from scope decomposition on a predictive (waterfall, traditional) project. In predictive projects, a work breakdown structure (WBS) is the most "popular" tool used to elaborate scope. In agile projects, one way to elaborate scope is by identifying the project's themes, then epics, features, user stories, and finally, tasks. In the scenario, the product owner suggests decomposing the epics into features. A feature is a set of related requirements or functionalities that provides value to the organization. Each feature is typically described using a short phrase, which represents specific behaviors of a product. Hence, the choice that provides this description represents the best answer to the question asked.

answers.answer_text: Identify large groups of customer value reflected as user stories associated by a common factor, such as functionality or data source
Create and document a clear and concise representation of a requirement written from the perspective of the product's end user
Define a set of related requirements and describe them using a short phrase, which represents specific behaviors of a product
Estimate the number of story points required to develop the project scope broken down into smaller more manageable parts

question_text: As the project completes its ninth iteration, the sponsor requests to see some metrics that would inform stakeholders on the project's performance and help them make decisions while planning the subsequent iterations. The project manager provides the sponsor with the number of defects that have been fixed in the first, second, and third iterations.
explanation: This question covers the topic of effective metrics. A popular way to define effective metrics is using the SMART criteria. According to these criteria, effective metrics should be specific (S), meaningful or measurable (M), achievable or agreed to (A), relevant or realistic (R), and timely or time bound (T). In the scenario, the sponsor is looking for metrics that would inform the project stakeholders on the project's performance and help them make decisions while planning the subsequent iterations. The project manager provides the sponsor with the number of defects that have been fixed in the first, second, and third iterations. These metrics meet some of the SMART criteria; for example, the number of defects fixed in past iterations is specific. Knowing that information may have some benefit. However, for the purpose of planning future iterations, these numbers are outdated and, therefore, are unlikely to help. Providing data from the recent iterations or even all iterations would be a better approach.

answers.answer_text: Provided not specific metrics
Has not consulted with the team
Provided outdated metrics
The project manager has done nothing wrong.

question_text: You are leading a project with a fixed budget to build 100 single-family houses in a new neighborhood. All the infrastructure work, such as the water supply, sewage, electricity, comms, roads, etc., has already been completed. All that is left is to construct the houses. The sponsor wants a return on investment even before the project is formally completed and closed. What is the best approach for you to meet the sponsor's request?

answers.answer_text: Construct the houses sequentially, one-by-one
Construct the houses together, all the same time
Crash the schedule using additional resources
It is unrealistic to meet the sponsor's request.

question_text: A project requires ongoing stakeholder engagement and needs to respond to high levels of change. The project manager selects a hybrid life cycle for the project and prioritizes the work items in a backlog. At the beginning of each iteration, the team determines how many backlog items they can deliver. Which project management process(es) will the project team need to repeat with each iteration?
explanation: Explanation: In the scenario described, a hybrid life cycle is selected for the project. Hybrid (or adaptive) projects are intended to respond to high levels of change and require close and consistent stakeholder engagement. Often the full scope of the project is not understood at the beginning of the project, or it evolves during the project. Therefore, the deliverables are developed over multiple iterations where a detailed scope is defined and approved at the beginning of each iteration. In a hybrid or adaptive life cycle, a high-level vision for the project is decomposed into an ordered list of requirements and work items which is contained in the backlog list. At the beginning of each iteration, the team determines how many of the items on the backlog list can be delivered with the iteration. Additionally, as the project progresses, new requirements/changes may be identified/requested. These actions are associated with the Collect Requirements process. The chosen requirements and

answers.answer_text: Processes are not performed on a hybrid project
Collect Requirements and Create WBS
Identify Stakeholders and Close Project or Phase
Collect Requirements and Define Scope

task: 2.13 Determine appropriate project methodology/methods and practices
question_text: For the next phase of an engine development project, the design engineer is unsure what type of meshing to use. Though the engineer is considering tetra-meshing, she wants to find out if there have been similar instances in previous projects and what type of meshing was applied. What is the best course of action?
explanation: Explanation: The engineer is trying to find what approaches have been used in similar projects in the past. Of the available options, only the organizational process assets have information from past projects, and this is where the engineer can get details on lessons learned, best practices, alternatives used in various situations, etc. Note, to correctly answer the question, it is not necessary to understand what tetra-meshing is, or how it works, because the question only asks where to find relevant information from past projects. Prospective PMP aspirants should keep in mind that questions on their exam may be vague and/or contain extraneous information.

answers.answer_text: Check the organizational process assets
Review the requirements documentation
Look for the information in the project charter
Meet with a team member who worked on a previous project

question_text: A software development project will use an iterative and incremental approach to produce project deliverables. What planning strategy would work best for this project?
explanation: Explanation: A software development project that will use an iterative and incremental approach to produce its deliverables implies the project will be using agile methods and artifacts. The reason for selecting an iterative and incremental approach in the first place is typically the extent to which project requirements are known (unknown) upfront. When there is ambiguity surrounding requirements in a project's early stages, teams can take high-level themes or epics provided to them by the customer or product owner and decompose them into features. Further decomposition may lead to user stories and other items added to the backlog and prioritized for the nearest iteration (sprint). As the project unfolds, the team would take the next set of epics and apply the same decomposition process. The cycle repeats itself until all project objectives are met or if a decision to stop the project (for whatever reason) is made.

answers.answer_text: Decomposing epics into features and further into user stories
Outsourcing project planning to an external subject matter expert
Breaking down high-level deliverables into work packages
Planning product scope and refraining from planning project scope

question_text: A product owner should focus on which of the following?
explanation: Explanation: The product owner is primarily responsible for maximizing the business value that is delivered to the customer. By focusing on delivering features requested by the customer, the product owner, along with the rest of the team, assesses, prioritizes, organizes, verifies, and validates the work to maximize value.

answers.answer_text: Providing innovative features to the customer
Conforming with agile ceremonies
Providing the features requested by the customer

In a project utilizing agile practices, there is a product review at some point or points in the iteration. Since most of the iteration is to get to a workable version for review, that often is at or near the end of the iteration. Whenever such a review happens, it is a tool and technique to examine and validate the project work and product deliverables. Inspections are sometimes called reviews, product reviews, and walkthroughs.

answers.answer_text: Validate the product scope
Manage product quality
Control the product scope
Close the project or phase

question_text: Gold plating had been an issue with your current software development project. However, you found that ever since instituting daily stand-up meetings, no more features or functionalities that the customer did not request have been introduced into the project. What is your best course of action to prevent gold plating for the remainder of the current project and on future projects?
explanation: Explanation: Daily standup meetings can be used by teams and stakeholders, often on agile projects, to share and discuss achievements and issues of the previous day as well as plans for the current day's work. The question suggests that you, as the project manager, have discovered that using daily standup meetings is beneficial in controlling the project scope. This hybrid project management practice, traditional scope control approach using agile methods, can be documented in the lessons learned register, which is a project document used to record knowledge gained during a project so that it can be used in the current project. At the end of the project or phase, the information in the lessons learned register is transferred into the lessons learned repository as an organizational process asset, where it can be used to improve the performance of future projects. Therefore, of the available choices, capturing the best practice in the lessons learned register is the best way to prevent g

answers.answer_text: Bring up the topic during the project retrospective
Capture the best practice in the lessons learned register
Gold plating adds customer value and should not be prevented
Ensure that the scope management plan includes daily stand-up meetings

task: 2.1 Execute project with the urgency required to deliver business value
question_text: You are leading a project that was supposed to be managed using agile methods. Every week, however, the product owner holds a five-hour backlog refinement meeting with the project team where she presents the project scope broken down to the work package level. After three iterations, the project team's velocity is slower than expected. What is your best course of action?
explanation: Explanation: The scenario suggests that the product owner is using a waterfall approach to decompose the product scope, whereas the question indicates that an agile project management framework is being used. In a traditional waterfall project, the project scope is decomposed down to the work package level to create the work breakdown structure (WBS). On agile projects, on the other hand, the product scope is captured in the product backlog, which evolves throughout the course of the project. Agile best practices recommend that teams allocate no more than one hour per week for backlog refinement. Such an approach would allow the team to maximize the time spent developing the product increment rather than creating a detailed plan. Instead of attempting to present an updated WBS every week, the product owner should just present the overall story concept to the team and then spend no more than an hour refining the stories.
